text: Bottle 0.75l sample at Ratebeer Belgian Winter Gathering 2017 Antwerp, Belgium at Beerlovers Bar 25.02.2017. Thanks everybody for sharing great beers! Pour it dark amber color with no head. Aroma caramel with some woody note. Taste harsh, sweet, molasis, caramel, creamy texture, something is missing here for my opinion, medium body, average carbonation, abrupt finish.
Geproefd @ RBBWG2017. Karamelkleur met kleine witte schuimkraag. De geur is zoet en hoestsiroopachtig. Smaak is licht bitter met een tikkeltje karamel.
Bottle @ RBBWG 2017. Many thanks for sharing! Hazy amber colour, white foam. Nose of caramel, Bit watered down. Not very good.
Sampled at the RBBWG2017 . Thnx for sharing, everyone ! Pours unclear amber, small white head. Smell is bit medicinal, oxidation. taste is full, sharp, a bit bitter. Creamy, earthy, some caramel.

Thank you kraddel! 750 ml. bottle sampled @ RBBWG VI (2017). 2013 Vintage. Amber orange, creamy tanned head. Nose is oxidized cellar with thick moldy orange peel sugar base, thick malts, fish gut yeast. Taste is thick cellar, medicinal orange peel, dried orange peel, very thick malts, sugar, stone fruits, dried citrus fruits peel. Very thick malt yeast base, cellar / oxidation notes are too obvious. Still pretty decent, bad oxidation is also too clear for me at this point.
750ml bottle pours out caramel topped with a sand head. Nose is rich malts pit fruit and some belg candy sugar. Taste is more of the belg candy sweetness pit fruit and light booze.
Bottle at Liquid Sunshine. Copper-red, brown, pretty. White tall foam. Woody metallic malt. Bright carbonation and Belgian overtones of course. Good.

Bottled. Pours murky copper, big beige head. Aroma is sugar, caramel, plums, candied figs, raisins, really nice, and a good sweet sugar feel. Flavor is similar, sweet, plums, figs, raisins, and actually a nice citrus hop presence that prevents it from getting too sweet. I really like it. Would love a barrel-aged version.

On tap at the Community Tap.
Dark golden body with very good clarity and a fine head. 
Well balanced flavor with good complexity. Plenty of Belgian yeast notes in the aroma.
Bottle. Brown pour with tan head. Spice, yeast, fruit Belgian aromas. Sweet Belgian candi sugars, dark sweet fruits, spice and yeast Flavors.

22 bomber to tulip glass. Pours clouded blood orange with moderate sediment, beige cream head. Aroma of banana, fig, clove, cinnamon and Belgian yeast. Taste the same with sweet dried fruit. Finish is semi-dry and doesnt last long.

Pours a medium brownish Amber, med white head. Aroma is caramel, earth, musty / earthy hop, floral, big malt, Belgian yeast. Flavor is a malt bomb, big sweet fruits, prune, banana, clove, light back ended hop.

Big beige head. Hazy brown body. Fruity earthy caramelly aroma with waxy notes. Dry-sweet earthy caramelly marzipan taste with alcohol notes. Mid-bodied. Mild, mealy mouthfeel. Dry earthy spicy fruity aftertaste with earthy watery notes. Nice and drinkable. (0.75l bottle shared by gr0ve.)

Bottle. Pours a hazy brown with thick head. Not a lot of aroma. Spicy beginning. Creamy mouthfeel. This is not my favorite style and I was surprised at how drinkable this was at 10%. There is a nice meld between the hop bitterness and the booziness that belies its high abv.
Tap at Track 84. Clear amber pour with a smaller head. Banana, clove, raisin. Pretty rich on the taste. Good stuff.

APPEARANCE - dark copper color, somewhat turbid. Strong frothy head with tremendous lacing. NOSE - extremely light Belgiany fruitiness. FLAVOR - builds on me as it warms and my palate warms up to it. Its subtle, hare to tell its 10%.

Medium amber, full body, high acidity, low carbonation and heat, moderate bitterness, flavor and sweetness, avg length. Spicy, cloves amd cinnamon. 
In the whole, pleasant. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
This poured a darker red color with a white head. Aroma was of Belgian yeast, caramel and dark fruits. Light eartthy choppy taste, dark fruits and yeast.
Tap. Pours a hazy amber with a thin layer of off white head. Aroma and taste of bananas, cloves, hints of yeast.

bottle from kihoskh. clear brown, offwhite to yellowish head. mild spicy slightly boozy aroma, malty, dry, nutty. flavor is malty, very round, very velvety, slightly sweet, but the very full flavor matches the alc. really well. bitterness is high, and its this kind of spicy yeasty bitterness you can find in belgian beer. dry and bitter quad, quite well done, but i think, slightly overrated at ratebeer.

Pours a hazy amber with a lasting off white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, some hops, and a little booze. Flavor is semi sweet, bitter caramel, slightly hoppy. Dry and bitter finish. You can feel the booze with a warming finish. Thick and chewy.

Cask at Porter Beer Bar in Atlanta. Poured into a tulip. Poured a moderate dark amber with a one finger velvet head. Aroma is caramel, spices, dark sugars, and grains, The taste is quite similar with the dark fruits and sugars, molasses, spices, and cereals. Moderate body and carb. Sweet finish.

Cloudy, mahogany brown, light tan head. Honey, molasses, some light cereal grain. Some other more subtle spice flavors. Quite sweet, some bitterness. Medium body, oily, some acidity. Long finish. Good.
Tap at Beer Authority, New York. Colour is cloudy orange with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Fruits, dark fruits, some sweetness and malts. Quite harsh in a bad way.
Draft. Dark gold in color. Flavor is dark fruits, booze, bread. Some banana is in there sweet but not too one of the dryer quads out there. Awesome.

On tap at the brewery. Pours clear dark amber with a white creamy to frothy head that leaves ok lacing. Not a lot of aroma but found whiffs of caramel and alcohol. Soft carbo, medium sour, lightly bitter, light to medium body, flavors of dark fruit, raisins and caramel with a bit too much alcohol showing through.

Flight at brewery. Interesting but overly sweet. Beutiful caramel colored pour- decent white head. Dried fruit, caramel and belgian notes. Slick mouthfeel. Some hop presence but left with lingering sweetness in the smooth finish. Boozy.

Free! Taster at the source. Pours reddish copper with an off white head. Aroma is clove, raisin, toffee. Flavor follows, caramel toffee backbone with clove, raisin. Dry clove and a touch of pepper in the finish.. Solid quad.

750ml bottle and tap. Pours a light brown color with a thin off-white head that falls quickly to a thin ring that stays to coat the glass. Very grapey, vinous aroma with plenty of caramel and dark fruit maltiness with raisin, plum, and cherry, and a good dose of herbal and floral citrus hop notes. Flavor begins with a toffee malt sweetness which lasts from start to finish. That is combined with flavors of dark fruits and spices. There is a presence of Belgian yeast and just a hint of bitterness in the finish that fades quickly. Medium body with creamy, very fine carbonation and a slight alcohol warming.

Bottle. Light hazy deep copper liquid with mediu off-white head. Aroma of raw sugar, toffee, red berries, licorice, light banana and light grain. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter with notes of red berries, toffee, licorice and light banana. Medium to full bodied with medium carbonation. Decent.

Nice dark fruit aroma, with some plum aromas in there. Taste is very smooth dark fruit maybe some raisin. Almost light for how strong it is. Not as banana yeasty as many Belgians. Smooth tasty quad, not as malty as some quads, but also not as sweet. Nice beer, but there are better quads. Maybe a notch below the tops

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

750 ml bottle. Pours a veiled ruby reddish brown to copper with a thick, resilient white head. Aroma is fruit, brown sugar and caramel. Flavor is lots of fruits, caramel, brown sugar, lavender, spices. Finish is cinnamon, herbs and some spices. Lingering soapy notes. Medium body, average carbonation.

Very good quad that is not overly sweet as some can be. Pour is medium amber with a large off white head. Aroma is nice but a little muted hops,malts and sweetness. The hop profile stands out with a nice caramel under tone.

"pours thick and a little lighter opaque brown than in the picture above. the aroma is nice. spicy and sweet. the mouthfeel thick. the flavor complex and spicy, but didnt stand out. good, not great. "

Pours a burnt amber brown with a white head. Malt, fruit, yeast, caramel and earthy hop aroma. Caramel, apple, pear, toffee, raisin, yeast, sugar and malt flavors. Medium full body and lively carbonation. Fruit, yeast and malt finish.

From a 750ml brown bottle. Medium orange colour, hazy. Small creamy tan head on top. Light nose with some winey notes and lemon. Some dark malt tastes, caramel malts/toffee, fruit sweetness. Overall a bit plain, didnt quite connect with this beer.

Bottle to tulip
Caramel, toast, beets, squash. Hazy amber, creamy white head. Gourd, biscuit, mace, oregano.
Bottle - Fig, dark fruit, dark sugars and yeast. Cloudy copper with a decent beige head. Sweet stone fruit, sweet sugars and a long finish. A little light for a quad, but still quite nice.

Bottle poured into a brandy snifter. Pours a clear brown to copper color with a beige head of foam. The aroma is sweet caramel and toffee. The taste is fairly sweet and fruity. Bug body and moderate carbonation.

Bottle thx to _angst_ cons 2014-08-23 Göteborg
AR: yeasty, pear brandy, nutty as well
AP: reddish mahoghny, frothy beige gead
F: belgian yeasty, almondy cake, warming feeling, dry, german marzipan, pear brandy, apple pie, rasins, wee grainy

Bottle 750 ml thanks to _angst_! Sampled on August 23, 2014. Batch Nov 21.2012.Hazy dark brown color, brown head. Alcohol, cheese, Herrgårdsost, light fruity scent. Sweet, alcohol, chestnut taste. Dry, harsh aftertaste. A bit of dandelion as well. Fizzy mouthfeel, medium low bitterness. Too noticeable alcohol. Also peppry.

Bottle bought @ Kihoskh. Pours hazy reddish brown with a big frothy goldenish offwhite head that leaves lots of sticky lacing and trace on the glass while dissipating. Smell is sweet and malty with dark bread, oatmeal, apple jam, pear skins, alcohol, hay, lemon zest and hints of glue and marzipan. Taste is sweet and malty with dark bread, oatmeal, caramel, apple jam, baked pears, marzipan, hay, dry soil and hints of lemon zest and alcohol. Mouthfeel is soft, round, tiny boozy and near full bodied. Finish is tiny sweet and malty with dark bread, oatmeal, hay, baked pears, apple skins, dry soil, marzipan, alcohol and lemon zest. Complex and quite tasty but a bit too heavy on the apple and pear phenols. Reminds me of Westvleteren 12 but less refined
Bottle. Amber colour with an off-white head. Flavour and aroma is sweet, malt, hop, berries, alcohol, sugar, pine, grass, dried fruits. Full body. Very nice beer.
Bomber to a pint glass. Light amber brown with ample off white head and lacing . Toasted grain, toffee and spice on the nose. Flavor follows, nicely balanced, refreshing!

Bottle. Pours crystal clear reddish amber with a large beige creamy head that dissipates slowly with nice lacing. Aroma is caramel, toffee, grass, dark fruits. Flavor is medium sweet, molasses present, perhaps anise as well. Light bitter. Medium body. Interesting and complex.

Une rare quadrupel blonde. En fait plutôt de couleur rousse ambrée, avec une mousse couleur crème. Rougeoyante à la lumière, et mi-mince. Nez fruité (pêches confites, abricots) et sucré. Au goût, ce sont des fruits jaunes confits, et une finale houblonnée qui fait penser à une tripel belge typique particulièrement costaude. Une des meilleures bières de ce type hors de Belgique, elle frôle la perfection, et profite dune belle originalité.

750ml bottle from notes. Pours a cloudy reddish brown color with a small off white head. The aroma and flavor have a heavy malt character, caramel, brown sugar, maple syrup, yeast, plums and raisins, port, oak, a hint of apple and some alcohol. Medium body, mouthfeel is smooth, good for sipping.

Bottle. Hazy hazelnut brown with a medium sized slowly diminishing good lacing white head. Caramel, alcohol, figs, over ripe banana, light flowery and spicy. Full body, oily texture, medium carbonation, medium sweet and bitter. Ok balanced, pleasant.

3-8-13: Pours a brilliant rose/orange color with a spongy orange tinted foam cap and big carbonation. Phenolic, champagne, fruit, lemon zest aromas. Flavors very complex in nature a nice coating sweetness yet dry and effervescent and warming character maybe a touch soapy,

UPDATED: APR 7, 2014 Sampled on draft at 3R6P this beer poured a very dark amber color with a large foamy orange-tan head that faded and left decent lacing. The aroma was tangy and sweet with notes of bread, honey, table sugar and golden fruits. The flavor was dryish and tangy with notes of bread and table sugar. Medium length finish. Moderately full bodied. Decent but fairly subdued for style.

Bottle at Fastelavn Smagning 2014 @ J&Cs beer palace, Jutland Saturday Session 1 - 01/03/14. 
Hazed orange amber with a well appointed off white covering that retains well.
Nose is fruit pie, spicey, dark fruits, toffee, light booze, ripe orange, dates, raisens.
Taste comprises caramelised sugars, fruit cake, light spice, dates, fruit cake.
Medium + bodiment, fine carbonation, sweet licks in the close and mellow boozeydoos.
Decent for style, never too hot or sweet.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle, 75cl corked. An unclear, dark amber beer topped by a dense, off-white head that lasts and leaves lacings. The aroma is fruity and sweet, with some dried fruits and white sugar. A bit boring, but sure nice. Some alcohol too, both in the aroma and flavor. Some bitterness to deal with the sweetness, with dried fruits, white sugar, pine cone notes and some grassy hints. Full body with some warmth. Lasting sweet, bitter and lighlty alcoholic finish. Overall, too sweet for my likings, but nice anyway. 140301

Bottle 750ml @ fonefan
Pours slightly hazy reddish brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes malt, caramel and dried fruits. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

75 cL bottle. Pours cloudy orange with a huge white head. Aroma is fruity and light toasted malty. Smooth malty and fruity. Bitter and toffee malty. Smooth malty and caramelish. Bitter and dry toffee malty. Ends mild sweet.

Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Hazy amber with a lasting off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, dark fruit, yeasty and a little alcohol. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish with warming finish. 010314

Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are caramel, fruits, malt, candy sugar and hops.

Dark amber with a beige head. Aroma contains figs, caramel, cherries, nuts, and spices. The flavor is malty and complex with tons of spices. Some alcohol shows up in the finish. Overall great for this cold ass day or any day.
Bottle. This is an incredibly delicious quad with lots of sweet belgian qualities and smooth malts.

Batch #21

A: Pours a hazy burnt toffee ale with a single finger of peanut head which dissipates quickly to leave a sheet of the same. Spotty lacing. when agitated, a full finger of fluff sticks around for a few minutes.

S: Initially, floral and metallic. Followed up by sweet belgian sugar, malts and earthy yeast. Some hints of green apple skins. Afraid this would not really benefit from more time in the bottle (and Im unsure of the age on this).

T: Sweet, yeasty, see above. At the back end, the alcohol sharpens and even stabs! Havent had anything this alcoholic in some time. Afraid this would not really benefit from more time in the bottle (and Im unsure of the age on this).

M: Medium-lo body with seltzer carbonation. The beer is a bit light on the palate for my preference in a quad. Leaves slick in the mouth.

O: A far cry from the quality Ive come to expect from Allagash. The beer is poorly balanced and overly alcoholic. With a mouthfeel inconsistent with the styles big dogs, this beer nearly disappoints. Last time I will buy this one.

Serving type: bottle

05-20-2011
750 ml. bottle. Thanks Luke! Pours reddish brown with a nice off-white head. Aroma of malt, fruit, spice, and caramel. Taste is malt, dark fruits, yeast, caramel, and spice. Very good.
Draft at Rustico Alexandria. Poured a dark copper color with a medium sized off-white head. Aroma was quite sweet, plenty of berries. Flavor was sweet malt, fruits, some hop notes. Pretty tasty.
Muddy brown pour with no head. Aroma and taste are dominated by a candy sweetness and some plums and raisins with a peppery spicyness in the yeast. not bad.
Clear copper pour with abundant toffee-tinted white head. Aroma is nutty with a little malty sweetness. Flavors are also nutty, dried fruit, yeast, prominent alcohol.

corked and caged bottle split with the wife. pours a burnt sienna hue, small off white head. big malty nose, plums, figs. taste continues with toast. bid body hides abv well, bit it hits hard, i am tired now.

Poured from bottle into shaker glass. Gorgeous copper amber color with a nice head. Deceptively strong. Hides the 10% ABV very well. Has some nice warmth but otherwise nothing harsh about this...so very smooth and mellow. Nice hop presence, with a good malt base. Reminds me of an east coast IPA but with more...goodness. Was lucky enough to spend some time in Maine recently and brought home quite a bit of Allagash. Just wish I had more!

Bottle shared with my dad at the lake house. Pours a somewhat hazed amber orange with a medium sized beige head. Big spicy malt, some faint stone fruit, big caramel. Medium-bodied, sweet and a little bit of tangy fruit with some warming alcohol. Warms up even more into the finish, warm, spicy, fruity, estery yeast. Big but very tasty.

Dark amber pour, two fingers of white head and huge carbonation. On the nose there is a lot of grain at first, then some hop brightness and fruity undertones. Taste is grainy, but more dark fruits become apparent as it warms, slight hop bitterness, Drinks well for 10%. One of the better offerings Ive had Allagash.

Une bouteille de 75 cl née le 8 mars 2013. Une robe qui mapparaît ambrée. Une tête bien représentée. Un nez très large, fruité à souhait, épicé et feuillu par ses houblons et capiteux par son Spécial B, ses notes rôties et ses notes légèrement grillées. Des saveurs finement réchauffées de caramel foncé, de pommes surettes et de raisins sucrés avec une touche de figue et des houblons habilement terreux, poussiéreux et justement épicés. Une bouche superbement densifié et extraordinairement éclairée par des bulles vivifées. Une texture qui donne une noblesse à mon palais comme le fait une fine liqueur fruitée. Une finale construite avec intelligence et dextérité sur des notes amères et chaudement fruitées. Un monstre si facile à boire et si digeste qui accompagne à merveille le feu de fin de soirée.

On tap at Frisco Tap House & Brewery in Columbia, MD. 

Hazy, rusty brown with a small off-white head and very good lacing. 

Aroma of apple, pear, brown sugar, caramel, cherry, fig dates and yeast. 

Taste of caramel, dates, figs , brown sugar, bread, fruit and herbal hops. 

Medium/full body and medium carbonation.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Wonderful. Pours cloudy orange with good head and lacing. Aroma of raisins, candied malt, figs, some booze and a touch of spice. Also some caramel in malt. Finishes with light sweetness and some tang. Soft carbonation. Thick consistency. Tap at brewery.

Pours murky amber with a thick head. Aroma is musty and husky. Flavor is sweet and sharp, bitterness and tanginess. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pour a maple brown color with good clarity and a finger of khaki bubbles. Lots of sweet caramel, toffee, prune, warm spice and banana bread.... light traces of citrus peel and yeast esters mingle nicely and dry out the finish. Tasty and well balanced.
Its a good beer. Definitely a must if youre fan of quads.............................................

Bomber: complex. Fruity nose of plum cashews. Viscous in a deep, slightly hazed caramel color with minimal head. Sweet forward with a balanced migration to a slight tartness. Very easy drinker. Love it! ~m

--RaucusBacchus

750 bottle from Holiday Wine Cellar. Batch Nov. 2012. Poured a clear amber with lace. Spicy nose with some pepper and citrus in the back. Alcohol is well hidden. Flavors not thick, but more delicate and complex. Well balanced. Yeasty candy malts with lite fruits. Slight barrel and vinous characteristics. Some pepper in the finish. Not quite a Abt/Quad, but very enjoyable.

On tap @ Rattle N Hum. A cloudy deep dark plum orange one almost a bit bronze with a nice medium sized off-white lacing top. Smells nice with a good malty sweetness, some fruity tones and a good dash of caramel. Not extreme at first to be honest, but I like what I smell. Its quite tasty, I get a herbal almost tea like thing here at first. Walnuts and nut cake with a soft acidity and yeasty undertones. Its thick and only on the mouthfeel with a soft prickling carbonation level. Served quite cold, but it opens more up on the nose after a while with a little bit of tobacco and dates. Not a super extreme beer, more balanced and something you can sip and enjoy. I sure did! 21.06.2013

Amber with light tan head. Aroma is slightly fruity. Flavor is bold and malty with a slight dark fruit flavor. Some hops round it out. Alcohol is well hidden.

Wife: 4.8
November 2010. Bottle. Dark amber color with a white head. Sediments floating around. Dried fruit, brown sugar, spice aromas. Fruity flavors with sugar and a mild alcohol burn at the end.
Rated in 2010 (Backlog) - Amber in color with a good sized off-white head. Aroma is of malt, yeast, and caramel. Taste is of yeast, light fig, and alcohol.
Bottle share. Cloudy dark amber with so much floating bits. Aroma of plum, raisin, vanilla, molasses. Taste is raisin, plum, molasses, vanilla.

Golden amber with a good off-white head. Aroma is raisins, honey, dates, candied citrus. Creamy mouthfeel, rich and sweet on the palate, lingering fruit finish. Taste is raisins, apricots, honey, dried fruits. Yummy.
Draft - pours amber with offwhite head and great lacing. Nose is prunes or old man fruit. Flavor adds booze and Belgian sugars. Sweet. The wife calls it smooth.
Very sweet, but not overly complex.  This one seemed a little bit messy.  Very little raisin/plum type flavors... mostly just white sugary sweetness.  Meh.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2013 Bottle to glass. Pours a deep hazy copper color with a light off-white head. Aroma is very sweet, with strong caramel and yeast notes, possibly a dull fruit mixed in. Flavor is quite yeasty, with sweet notes lingering in the finish. Mild alcoholic notes as well. Medium body with an average carbonation. Solid beer.

Pulling this one out after several years in the cellar, corked and caged, has got to be from late 2009 or earlier, definitely somewhere from the 2006-2009 period (was hoping for a date on the cork but no luck).  Nose is very dense, dulled malt, still a little sweet under the alcohol, very rich and grapey, intense, some very fruit and minerally yeast, muddled caramel.  Pours a turbid, murky brown with little head.   Taste is sweet but its under control, smooth yeast overwhelming all hops, some nice sugar afters, a lot of very genteel and rounded alcohol.  There really is a wonderful... adult, refined quality here, the sort of aging and distillation found in an old port or brandy, the medium-full body is as smooth as anything liquid.  Perhaps lacks the depth it had when fresher, but the tender caress of a novel "spirited" beer is a treat of its own.
Bottle. I really like how Allagash spices their beers, and this is no exception. Very rich flavors may be too much for some, but I love the aggressiveness of Four.
750 ml bottle pours a cloudy brown color with a small white head.  Aromas of Belgian yeast, dark fruit, candied sugar.  Full bodied, sweet sticky finish

Bottle.  Pours reddish-brown with a medium tan head.  Aromas of dark fruits, sweet malt, moderate yeast, light wood and light spice.  Similar flavor.  More balanced as it warms.  Some alcohol in the finish.

Location/Date:Bottle split with Dave on 5/11/2013.
Appearance: Pours a cloudy orange. 
Aroma: Aroma of light fruit.
Taste: No bitterness, light fruit, wood.
Palate:Light body, no fizz, covers alcohol well.
Summary: A nice well made american quad.
Aroma slight hint of rye.  Appearance golden redfish color. Very slight white head taste of cherries paltatr ling on flavor.

From a 75 cl bottle shared in Avon NC.  Pours a light cola with a thin off white head.  Light cherry aroma.  Flavors of caramel, light toffee, red fruits and some feint sour yeast notes.  Medium mouthfeel with light carbonation.  Hides the alcohol well.

Really not much scent. Malty, typical Belgian aromas like dark fruit, brown sugar, caramel, pumpernickel. Low carbonation, leading to a semi-sweet, slightly liquory taste, which you have to expect at a whopping 10% ABV. Worst part is the aftertaste, sticky and sweet. Very good beer, though.

This beer has very little aroma. It is crisp and goes down easy. It is less sweet than your normal Belgian. Good clean flavors. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A good, if not a little boring beer. Pours a cloudy brown with a light white head. Not much smell. Taste is alright, smooth and refreshing but a little boring. Had on tap at Noc Noc.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I pick up on the scent of yeast, hops, malts, fruits, wine, and wood. The flavor is mainly of malts, hops, and fruit. I do taste yeast, a slight sweetness from the sugar, and dried fruits. Which might be apricots. There is minimal dryness in the finish. The drink isnt easy on my palate. The Four is a tad bitter but tends to fade quickly.  Overall this is a nice beverage.

Bottle from sampling session. 2009 vintage. From notes (Nov. 12, 2011). Very smokey nose. Lightly fruity and malty. Hops are apparent in the aftertaste. Age maybe helped, or maybe not. I suspect something was wrong with this bottle.

The smell has the raisin, Belgian yeast, light sugars and light banana all combined very nicely. The appearance has a small white head that lasts about a minute. The taste is extremely sweet, ranging close to a malt bomb. The palate is heavy and a bit sharp here and there. This is not very drinkable and am feeling my palate is wrecked after this bad boy. Overall, Im still fairly new to this style, but liked it for me.

750ml bottle. Dark brown sugar or caramel colour, a little lighter than I expected. Very little off white head. Aroma is yeasty, peaches, raisins, red wine. Light spice, banana, sweetness, moderate dried fruit, yeast and red wine. Light carbonation in the body. Quite smooth. Overall, reminded me some of wine or a light barley wine.

Pours beautiful, tastes verry Allagash. Standard yeastiness. Hops are more prevalent than other Allagash beers. Solid well put together beer, but nothing altogether earth shattering. I would buy again but for the price.

From notes: Bomber labelled Batch #26.  Poured hazy orange-brown with a thick, creamy 1-finger bone-colored head.  Sweet nutty malt aroma mixed with citrusy hops and a touch of yeast.  Body was a bit fuller than medium, with a mild syrupy thickness.  Finish is somewhat dry.  Flavor has a slight tartness up front, maybe citrus peel.  Mild caramel malt underneath, mixing with bready yeast.

Ambrée et voilée, ayant une mousse dense et persistante qui sagrippe aux parois en signant dune dentelle baveuse. Des arômes fortement maltés et de levure jouent les premiers violons, alors que des écorces dorange viennent se joindre à ceux-ci. Un goût un peu mieux nantis, en loccurrence par des saveurs dagrumes, dépices, de levure et dalcool, pour former un groupe uni. Le liquide se promène bien en bouche. Une légère amertume est ressentie. Elle est bien baraquée et lalcool fait son travail. Batch 28 Merci Louis! (469-251112)
Shared bottle at craft ale house. Pours clear copper with almost no head. The aroma Is candied sugar with some dark fruits. The taste is sweet with some fig and virtually no alcohol.

Believe it or not this beer has some pumpkin undertones and light spices to go with it. Beautiful orange glow. Pretty much a one time try at this price. Very delicious and drinkable. Mild and easy going. The sweetness is there but in no way overbaring. Classy beer. Of the many four element combinations in this beer they all are blended so well that they all become one. Some what muted.  So not one ingredient stands out on its own.
Pours amber with a red tint. Nice aroma of bread and fruit. The flavor is slightly sweet with a nice balance. Long lasting finish.

Hazy and bubbly red-orange, medium small light tan lingering head.  Aroma is yeasty, caramel, grapes.  Medium-full body, some carbonation, alcohol presence minimal.  Flavor up front is sweet and yeasty and bread-like.  Also medicinal cherry flavor and some citrus.  Hops are prominent leading to a dry finish.  The hops do a good job of providing balance to the sweetness, but not sure if added the right mix of flavors.  Still good though although pricey.

On-tap at The Trappe Door in Greenville, SC

A: Pours a deep copper color into the Trappe Door tulip glass. Good head, good retention

S: Cherries, wood, lots of residual sugar, banana, and hints of Belgian yeast, raisin. Alcohol does come through in the nose, but does not mask the rest

T: Super malty, including notes of cherries, dark fruit, candied fruit, raisin, banana, and a little spearmint. Kind of sweet, but alcohol is not noticeable at all, despite its 10% ABV

MF/O: Thick body, velvety, creamy feel, finishes a little sweet with hints of candied dark fruit

Inviting looking beer, ruby reddish brown in color, one finger fizzy, smooth head.  Nice aroma of raisin and currant flanked by touches of dark chocolate, spice, and yeast.  Upfront, taste is a little lacking, but the middle gives way to a nice wave of Belgian spice followed by dark cherry and more raisin before a subtle dash of toffee bitterness finishes it off.  A touch of metal lingers post-swallow.  Reminiscent of a quad but lighter bodied and more carbonated.  Good, but not a homerun and wouldnt buy again at store price.

Pours a clear amber brown with a high tan foamy head that laces heavily.  Smells a lot like a saison with green apple and plum, but also with caramel and Belgian yeast. A little bitter and sour for a quad with underplayed sweetness. Light bodied and dry for the style as well. A lot of interesting characteristics but the final product seemed a bit unbalanced.

From Batch 25. It pours a rich deep amber with red highlights and a foamy, puffy, tan head which is very soft and light. The aroma emits a character of dark malts, candied sugar, dried fruit, butter, and low hops with the 10% ABV barely to be found. The body is full. With the taste I get sweetness at first followed quickly by a slightly boozy flavor that was hiding in the aroma.  But it rips through my senses like Dristan nasal decongestant spray but quickly mellows to a lingering, dry finish.  This is good!

Pours a reddish orange amber. Aroma of tart grapes. Taste is malty and tart with a mild hop offset. Finish is tart and peppery. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Big Bottle, OBX.   Poured a ruby amber color with generous head.  Aromas of belgium candy, some ripe fruits, grapes, raisin.  Medium body, above average carbonation.  Medium sweetness.  Alchohol is fairly hidden.  Nice mouthfeel.  Taste about same as aroma.  Enjoyed this.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2012 Draft at Moriartys. Dark honey brown pour. Early in the keg came with a big pillowy head, later just some light foam. Tastes like raisin marmalade. Dried figs and dates. Toasted sugar cane. Caramel covered apples. Chai spice. Sprinkle of black pepper. Barrel aged red fruits. Medium body. Semi-smooth finish. Nice, but the spice does not quite balance off the sweetness. Update: Had again at Farmers Cabinet. Still a big foamy head. Most of the above still applies but the flavors feel more gentile and balanced this time.

Pours a deep orange with a heavy long lasting cream head and lots of lacing.

Aroma is very subtle which is kind of surprising for the style hints of alcohol and citrus are present alsoa  slight sourness lingers

Flavor is bold and dry, nice belgian characteristic, hints of dry aged fruits are also noticeable lingering dry and bitterness but very pleasant.

A quality quad.

Aromatics are light but you do get a lot of heat. It pours a fantastic burnt orange with a stiffer solid head that liners. Lot of sweet bitter tastes with this brew. Very typical Belgian tastes. Overall I like this a lot but theres no wow this is different factor.
Pours a cloudy red/brown. Aroma of sweet toffee, molasses and yeast. Flavour is the same as the aroma just with some dark fruits in there too. Full bodied, and the ABV is really well hidden.

On tap at RattlenHum.  Sweet, floral aroma.  Amber pour.  A little light-bodied for a quad, although the ABV is plenty high.  Some chocolate, molasses, and interesting fruity notes.  Not the greatest quad ever, but a fine brew.

Pours cloudy brown with a medium head and good amount of lacing. Aromas were muted with some malt caramel, alcohol, and phenols. Flavors seemed equally muted with malt caramel up front followed by yeast and spice with some fruitiness mixed in. Mouthfeel was creamy but carbonated with a dry finish. For a brew with 4 malts, 4 sugars, hopped and fermented 4 times, it was devastatingly lacking character. 

--- Cheers

Style et résumé: Quad américaine 4 malts 4 houblons.  
Comment: Dégustation au Mondial 2012. 
Description: Belle bière ambrée avec une mousse généreuse. Les houblons sont bien intéressant parmi ce malt très imposant. En bouche le liquide est sucré, le malt caramel ou crystal lemporte sur les autres malts. Un produit singulier de grande qualité. 
Note:  7+/10

On tap at Lunar Brewing Co., and snifter served with a deep, clear & bright, orangy amber hue, a modest layer of off white/light cream toned head foam, and waves & streaks of lacing. The aroma was light yeast, mid-fruit, currant, light spice, and  touches of tartness & sweetness. Warming alcohol was prevalent in the flavor almost immediately, then the aroma notes, with more pronounced tartness and candy sweetness, moderate to low hop bitterness, a little less than medium body, and closer to soft carbonation, which together prompted the perception of a little thinness in the texture. The finish was subtly bitter and dry, with the entire experience a rather flavorful one.

Draft at pony bar in an effort to dethrone the villain, hivemind. Pours an amber with white lacing. Aroma is muted for the most part. Mouthfeel is thick and syrupy with notes of booze, prune, sweet malts, barley, sugarcane, and spices.

Tap. Pours hazy amber with thin, fizzy white head; short retention and spare lacing. Aroma is caramel and biscuit malt, dark fruit, floral hops, and herbs. Flavor is malt forward with good supporting hops and fruit esters; dry, semi-sweet finish. Medium body, carbonation, and warmth.

S: thin off-white head, small bubbles, some lacing, dark, hazy gold

A: mild smell, strong alcohol, malty

T: like a tripel, rich, balanced, masked strength, finishes short to medium and slightly sweet

O: really solid, good, strong, well-rounded

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2012.04.04 - 750ml bottle in pint glass. Pours a mostly opaque medium copper orange.  A foamy light ran multi-finger head subsides very slowly, leaving a full thick cap.  You can hear it.  Aroma is raisins and sugars, to my nose.  Taste is a very smooth sweetness.  Complex flavors, like raisins and more.  There's a good bit going on.  Alcohol is hidden very well.  This is pretty tasty.   This is my second tasting, I immediately bought a few bottles after the first taste.

Pours a copper brownish color with a small creamy head.  Nose is sweet with dark fruit, peach and raisen.  Taste is sweet with remnants of yeast, dark fruites, spices and caramel malts. Medium bodied.
Man, this was good. Dark pour, very sweet complex flavor; raisins, chocolate and yeast primarily.

Pours cloudy brown with a medium head.  Caramel malt, apple, candy sugar, and a little sour funk in the aroma.  Flavor starts sweet and finishes with fruit, carbonation, some spice, and a little hop bitterness.  A nice special-occasion beer.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Chestnut red-brown body, thinish off-white head, spotty lacing.

S: Port-like dark fruits (raisins and prunes), caramel, spicy yeast, and brown sugar.

T: Lots of booze-soaked raisins, sugary-malts, spice, some vinous notes.

M: Medium-full bodied, moderate carbonation, a bit flabby and some residual booze in the finish.

O: A bid quad style beer that is lacking in the overall depth and refinement of the Pannepots, St Bernardus, Westvleteren and Rochefort.

bottle shared with dad. A: Spicy, ca ramel, bready. App: dark copper small white head. T/p. med to full body finish is sweet and medium long. O: nice love the subtle spicy bouquet no alcohol warmness at all.

750mL bottle, pours a cloudy dark amber with a small beige head. Aroma of dark fruits, brandy, red wine and candied sugar - omnipotent on the nose. Flavour of brandied fruits, candied sugar, red wine, slight booze but not overpowering. Full-bodied and smooth, incorporating the ABV exceedingly well. Delicious.
UPDATED: FEB 2, 2015 Rich medium dark brown ale. yeasty aroma. Tasty stuff. Some spices. A little crisper at the end that I would have thought. The missus enjoyed it too. Serving: Bottle

Pour is a dakr cloudy mahogany color with a small with a small khaki head. Nose is of deep malts and little bread. Taste is different, much sweeter with a bit more of a wine like finish, bit dry with a bit of a bitter finish, though nothing unpalatable for a beer.

750 ml bottle into tulip, batch 18(2008 bottling I think).  Pours very hazy dark red color with a small fairly dense khaki head with good retention that reduces to a thin cap.  Some spotty lacing on the glass.  Aromas of huge raisin, prune, banana, caramel, molasses, candi sugar, and yeast spices.  Nice aromas with big fruitiness.  Taste of big raisin, prune, caramel, toffee, toasted malt, molasses, candi sugar, biscuit, and yeast spices.  Lingering notes of molasses, toffee, dark fruit, and yeast spices on the finish for a while.  Medium carbonation and fairly full bodied; with a very creamy and slightly slick mouthfeel.  Alcohol is extremely well hidden for 10%, with hardly any warming after the  finish present.  Very smooth and drinkable, but it is still a sipper.  Overall this is an outstanding Belgian Quad with tons of great flavor and balance.  I would definitely have this again.

Pours a cloudy brown-orange with a thin white head. Aroma is mostly spiciness and Belgian yeast. Taste is sweet, bready, grain, vanilla and a bitter citrus finish. Not bad but there are better Belgian ales.

Bouteille de 750 ml, âgée denviron 1 an et demi. Arômes de fruits mûrs et de caramel brûlé. Présence de levure rappelant le pain frais. Magnifique robe cuivrée et légèrement trouble, très belle mousse qui tient bien et effervescence active. En bouche, on ne retrouve pas la touche de sucre candi des exemples traditionnels, mais plutôt une belle présence de céréales caramélisées et de fruits confis. Très légère présence de madérisation. Finale donnant une belle impression de sécheresse, accentuée par leffervescence très active. Lalcool est apparent en finale, mais demeure bien intégré au profil des saveurs.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy caramel brown, with a medium off-white head.  Aroma of yeast and brown sugar.  Fairly complex flavor - sweet and malty, with flavors of raisin and spice.  Nice yeast character.  A little bit of hops on the finish, although the aftertaste is odd in some sips.  Pretty solid, though.

Bottle @ home with Jetson. Batch 24. Pretty clear, copper orange appearance with a fluffy, tan head. Carbonated, spicy Belgian yeasty, toasty caramel malty, mild brown sugar aroma. Fairly rich candy sugar, brown sugar, toasty caramel malty, mild toffee, slightly fruity flavor. Really more like a Belgian Strong Ale. Easy to drink but not what I would usually consider a Quadrupel.

750ml bottle. Pours a clear amber with a white head.
Smells of brown sugars, and malt, hops and yeast.
Tastes of a heavy sweetness. Body is medium. Texture is syrupy. Carbonation is medium but soft. Finish is a tingly alcoholic sensation.

Very drinkable.

So we had this from the bottle at a tasting and as stated: Four means four malts, four yeasts and four hops were used at four different times. Being ~10%, I can say that it would need these different additions to create the taste. Tho I didnt rate this as high as the others I tasted, it did have a great dark almost porter characterstic. Carmel and chocolate to a roasted note. Hazy with a rocky, off-white head that lasted for the glass. Apple and honey notes also present.

Batch 24 .. Cloudy amber pour thin off white head light sticky lacing ..... aroma of sugar, caramel malts and a little grainy  ..... taste is of sugar, sweet dark fruits, faint floral hops, candi sugar, toasted caramel malts and a bit grainy .... finish is simple and of dry caramel malts .... abv hidden very well

11/29/11. 750mL bottle cracking in honor of finishing my lecture recital today! Not necessarily a special bottle, but Ive never bought this bottle because it is a bit pricey for me... so here we go! Hazy light brown pour with a nice, thick tan head that cuts in half but sticks and laces quite a bit in big, thick sheets. Somewhat plain aroma but theres definite metallic aspects, a touch of sweetness, and a nice small dose or roast. Sweet, burnt caramel flavors at first followed by another metallic dose, and a little bit of roast. Lingering metallic aspects, sweet caramels, and a solid dose of yeastiness as well. Not too shabby!
Aroma of clove and banana.  Pours red with a sticky head.  Tastes of alacohol, clove, banana and spices.  Delicious but in moderation (hic).

750 bottle, tasted blind.		
Medium amber, light lace. 
Caramel and fruit nose. Rather bland. A bit of hop and phenols. 
Fruity, hoppy, some orange and raisin. 
Rather light, smooth. Perfectly fine, though kind of boring.

a corked caged bottle. Color is a deep rust with heavy head and good lacing The aroma is a mix of light fruits like apple and dark fruits like fig. Also a little honey comb candy int here. Taste starts a little hops and candy fruit yeast. A quick touch of booze taste. Washed away by a fine carbonation. A lighter bodied quad. Very very good

(750ml bottle from Whole Foods Hillcrest-batch 24).  Pours an orange-copper color with light tan head.  Aroma is candied sugar, cotton candy, turbinado.  Taste is sweet with some bitterness and an unfortunate metallic note. Medium bodied with a slick texture.  Finish is somewhat dry, with a little carbonation fizz on the tongue.  Alcohol is noticeable, but its pleasant.  In spite of the metallic note, this is a pretty nice beer.  I would consider this more often if the price was lower (St. Bernardus Abt 12 is several dollars cheaper).

On tap at Churchkey. Pretty almond colored pour with a vivacious head. I like that this beer doesnt pretend to be Rochefort 10 or the like; it is decidedly a lighter quad in its complexities. The dark fruit characteristics to me bring out more candied sugars, red plum, nectarine, and light vinous notes, as opposed to the rich fig/raisin of those darker quads. Palate is sweet but not cloying, and full mouthfeel meshes with a soft but subtly present effervescence. As usual a very nice effort from Allagash.

750ml bottle in a Trappist glass.  Pours amber/brown with a thick, lacy, light beige head.  Aroma of caramel and slightly roasted malts, spicy yeast, and floral slightly grassy hops.  Flavor about the same with the yeast and caramel strong.  Average texture.  A pretty good quad.
Bottle poura a hazy brown with a thin off white head. Scent is dark fruit, yeast and wood. Taste is dark fruit, wood and bready.

Allagash
Four Ale
Pours coppery with light brown highlights. Smallish tan head with good retention. Aroma is big and bready with candi sugar and dark fruit aromas on the underside. Alcohol became present as the beer warmed. Flavor was smooth fresh baked bread and mildly sweet candi sugar. Boozy and packed a punch. Mild hop note on the finish provided a nuanced earthiness. Very good, but too damn expensive to buy more than occasionally.
Dark, not a lot of head.  Aroma is of fruit and followed by sweet flavors of dark fruit.

On tap at unos in neshaminy. Aroma of dark fruits,  yeast.   Taste is biting, alcohol, fruit, yeast,   sweet malt, vinegar.  Not told what it was, I thought it was a russian river beer. Should tell you enough.  Surprisingly good.

[Bottle] shared by Dan. Thanks! Pours clear burnt caramel with a small soapy white head. Aroma is light fruit snack, mint, sweet malt. Flavor is light cheese, fruity yeast, a little alcohol, lightly grainy and bitter. Finish is balanced between sweet and bitter.

Batch 15, I believe around 08.  Pours a dark brown, caramel hue.  Spices and darker fruits in the nose.  Palate is smooth with tons of flavor, I really thought this one would have diminished more, however the plum caramel flavor is straight through.  Still balanced and not cloying, maybe could have gone at least another year.  I will update with the last batch of the old label soon.  Quite tasty even on a warmer summer day
Draft. Pours amber with an off white head. Dark fruity aroma, with toasty malts, yeast, and a hint of booze. The flavor has spicy yeast, dark fruits, and toast. Nice.

drank at mondial 2011 in mtl. pours hazy golden orange with an off-white head, excellent retention and lacing. aroma is yeasty and orange-citrusy. malt and pepper, medium hopping - herbal-grassiness. medium to full body, belgium bubbly.

Pours amber-brown with a moderate white head and light lacing. Nose is a little earthy/herby for the style, but with plenty of brown sugar, maple syrup, belgian yeast, and some alcohol. Flavor is more typical of quads with rich, sweet breadiness, and yeast on the front, fading to fruit and alcohol on the backside. Very "sticky". Good stuff, though not quite up to the top pier among quadrupals.

Sample at Mondial de la Bière (Montréal). Cloudy amber body with an average off-white foamy/creamy head. Well balanced malty/hoppy aroma with grainy and flowery hints. Alcohol is very well hidden. Its malty/hoppy taste carries yeasty and fruity notes. Ends with a decent bittersweet finish. Very enjoyable Quadrupel.

Bottle sampled at Mondial de la bière 2011. Hazy amber with a thin off-white head with good retention. Aroma is sweet malt, spicy notes, yeast, alcohol and dark fruits. Flavor is candy sugar,  malt, spices, alcohol, dark fruits and yeast. Full body.

Bottled. Hazy ambery brown colour with a small beige head. Aroma is raisins, wood, resins, mild yeast and also being rather strong on the malty times. Flavour is rather siilar along with alcohol and some syrupy notes. Gets more balanced and bodied once it warms up a bit.

Bottle from halls liquors.  Pours a deep cloudy amber with a thin off white head.  The aromas are leather, bread.  The mouthfeel is dry, bitter and sticky with a medium to heavy body.  I really liked this one.  Cheers!

[bottle]
Musty grape aroma with some phenolics. Hazy light brown with a thin ring on top. Sweet sugary flavour that is musty with some slightly "wild" cherry. Light to medium body, moderate carbonation.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2013 Very interesting...first quad Ive had that was of a golden hue...not a dark fruit, purple color.  Draft at pizzeria paradiso Dupont....pours with little to no head.  Drinks smooth and sweet, with that natural sugar coming through very strong and smooth.  Very lightly carbonated.  I enjoyed trying this....I also have a bottle I plan to age for a while,...but it didnt blow me away. 3.5

Second taste on a 3 year old bottle...much better.  Pours smooth, low carbonation, sweet, tons of flavors of different fruits, apples, cherries berries.  Also some nice yeast character.  Dry finish.  Great beer.

Served in a snifter. Reviewed from notes.

Pours a moderate brown color with a bit of a reddish character. Single finger of white head and a touch of lacing. The nose brings a bit of caramel as well as a light bit of dark fruit. A bit of yeast character comes through as well.

The flavor is slightly sweet along with some mild dark fruits and a bit of light caramel taste. A slight amount of bread crust. Mouthfeel is a bit light with low-ish levels of carbonation. Interesting and nothing wrong, but doesnt quite hit the mark.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-20-2010

The beer pours a very untypical color for a quad forcing me to ask the bartender if I was given the right drink. It is a super light brown with tons of amber highlights. Its almost totally redish in the light. The head is light tan, super foamy with good retention and lacing. 

The aroma is pretty light, you get mostly bourbon on the front, sweet closes (no yummy malts), and an on oaky finish. It smells ok, just weird for a quad.

The taste keeps up the weirdness. When I think quad I want dark fig malts etc. All you get is oak and alcohol.

The feel is way to warm and has a weird aftertaste.

Overall, not impressed here. First of all, this may be made like a quad, but its no quad. Even if I can get past the improrper making of a great style, its just not a great tasting beer anyway.

Decanted into a wide-mouthed, stemmed glass from a corked 750ml bottle.

The Four pours a hazy reddish orange that glows like the sun against the light.  A huge vanilla colored head easily erects into a cloud-like froth.  It hangs around for several minutes and leaves thick lacing behind.  

The aroma starts mild, you really have to dip your nose into the glass to pick up its nuances.  It smells of sweet malts, light hops, and tons of fruity esters that remind me of bananas and tropical fruits.  There is the slightest hing of alcohol, too.  Once the head dissipates, though, the aromas really come alive.  

Palate is clean and full, with layers of flavors that arrange themselves perfectly.  I can feel it all over my tongue, mouth, lips, everywhere.  Theres a good amount of carbonation to keep things lively.  Malty flavors throughout, with medium hop bitterness, a little biscuit, toasted malt, dark fruits, and maybe some red currants.  Hints of butterscotch, too.  The beer finishes with a heavy malt presence, similar to a scotch ale or wee heavy.  The experience never shows the beers 10% ABV.  

This another great offering from Allagash.  A very flavorful, unique, drinkable beer.  Not a session beer, but it can go with or without food.  Its so heady in its appearance, aroma, palate, and taste.  Ill definitely buy a couple of bottles for the cellar.

Poured into a snifter. Four pours a rich amber/mahogany, with a solid white head with good retention. Very nice lacing as well. Aromas are of fall fruits, apples, pears, figs, and some golden raisins, as well as winter spices. Tastes match these aromas perfectly, very fruity mixed with clove and nutmeg, sweet and wonderful. Mouthfeel is smooth, not too heavy for a quad, and just outstanding. I could drink this forever, almost like I did when I toured the brewery and they had the FOUR w/ strawberries...try drinking that at 9:30 am..it was great.

Pours hazy dark amber with a thick, foamy, off white head.  Aroma is strong sweet malts, caramel, and some ripe fruit.  Taste is very malt dominated, there are a few hoppy hints here and there, but their bitterness is very subdued.  Some slightly tangy orange notes comes through at the finish, almost a hoppy citrus flavor.  There is also a good amount of booze on the finish.  Mouthfeel is lively, as this is a strongly carbonated brew.  Not my favorite Allagash, but a decent example of the style.  However, it simply does not compare to the good Belgian Abts.
More of an abbot than a quad, which is good.  Dark copper color. Lots of yeast in the aroma and flaavor.  Sweet malt with spices.  Some cardamom. Sweet finish.  Not a huge hop character in this one.

750 ml bottle shared by dbsdelight- thanks again, Dan! 2009 vintage. Pours a somewhat cloudy amber color with a finger-thick off-white head. Aroma of apples, grapes, wet dog, caramel malts, and earth. Flavor of apples, grapes, minerals, wet leaves, overripe fruits, caramel malts, and wood. Medium-bodied, with a malty, earthy mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Very weird quad.

Bottle pours reddish brown color with huge foamy golden head.  head persists with excellent lacing.  Aroma dark fruits and alcohol.  Taste sweet and slightly tart with dark fruits, spices and slight hops.  Brief finish of dark fruits and hops, slight alcohol burn on end.  Palate not particularly thick or rich but OK.

Overall I liked it.  One of the better US quads.
very malty profile, I feel all the malts are overwhelming and lost in this beer. alcohol masked well, otherwise great geer

Medium red/brown hazy color with average off-white head. Aroma is heavy malty, sweet, fruity with light hops and yeast.  Alcohol is noticeable but not overwhelming. Flavor is moderately sweet. Full body and oily texture.Light carbonation.

Thanks MilkmanDan.
amber/brownish pour
Aroma was  earthy, woody. slightly sourish.
Flavour was fruity, woody, earthy yeastiness. bit of a sourish tartness to it.
Not very quad like. But interesting to try.
Very spicy.  The body tastes of belgian yeast and fang sourness.  A little stale.  Thanks to Milkman Dan.

Bouteille de 750 ml, avec bouchon de liège, partagée lors dune dégustation Ratebeer Montréal. Arôme: Odeur de caramel sucré avec une pointe fruitée. Apparence: La couleur est ambrée. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de caramel fruité et sucré avec une pointe dépices et dalcool. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût légèrement fruité. (Rating #3443)

Bomber shared by someone..
Appearance : Clear amber with no head. 

Aroma : Quite spicy and sugary. Some yeast. Nice fruits, nice sugars.

Taste : Yeasty and quite spicy. Some alcohol. A bit warm. Soft carbonation. Bitter finish with sugary notes. Some anise.

Overall : Nice finish. Nice sugar. A bit too spicy for my taste. Not my kind of beer really. Well made and everything... just not my thing.
Thanks to Travlr: Poured a copper color with a jello bubble thin head. Aroma is fermented fruit and malt. Taste is very malty with a mix of fruit and nice hops as well.

Batch 19.  Great yeast aromas come first followed by dark fruit, slight chocolate and more alcohol as it warms.  Taste adds to the chocolate impression plus candi sugar, light molasses and a good alcohol warmth.  A very slight floral aroma and slight bitter finish become more evident as it warms further.  Great beer.
Draft.  Hazy brown body with an off-white head.  Aroma and flavor of dark fruit, fig, sweet malt, Belgian yeast.  Nice alcohol warmth and finishing bitterness.  Also, a little spicy.  Great brew.

Multi-hued golden orange color with a nice antique white head. Spicy apple and distinctive belgian yeast aroma. Silky texture, full body. Mild, velvety feel. Sudden bite. Rhubarb, fig and spicecake flavors. Fizzy finish.

On tap @ Rattle N Hum.
Hazy brown with an off-white head. Strong fruity aroma with some hints of dark fruits, caramel, and spices. Medium to full body with a hint of an alcohol bite. Quite good.

750 ml bottle

Sitting for the cellar for far too long I finally got this out of the back of a fridge. An excellent beer it was a little too pricey to pick up again with so many other choices. Regardless I would not hesitate to drink more if somebody was to open a bottle at a tasting or elsewhere. Allagash has yet to make a beer that has really disappointed me.

Aroma / Appearance - The rosy bronze body was dim as it absorbed most of the ambient light. A mildly dirty white head coupled with a sheet of delicate film added more depth. The scent of white grape juice combined with vanilla, caramel, roses just past their prime, and a little bit of hoppiness were not as robust as I was expecting. Regardless it was still reasonably well balanced and inviting.

Flavor / Palate - Caramel, cherry cordial, and chocolate mousse give this a dessert like touch. A dry maple syrup wraps up the experience with a little ribbon. The alcoholic tone does eventually break through after a few sips. I can only guess there are more hops when this is fresh but in its current state the results are far from disappointing. I would probably choose other quads when shopping around but at $11.99 the price was not too bad.

A hazy brown beer with a huge beige head. Aroma is fruity and yeasty, notes of dark fruits, toffee and wood. Taste is malty and fruity, notes of caramel, sherry. Some is spiciness. Noticeable alcohol.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a hazy golden amber with a small tan head leaving a large amount of lacing on the glass.  Aroma is alcohol, raisins, fig, caramel.  Taste is sweet with raisins and caramel.  Strong alcohol on the finish.  Medium body.  Light-medium carbonation.

Sampled at Allagash after the tour. Hazy to unclear amber with a medium beige head. Sweet aroma with roasted malt, caramel, dark overripe fruits, yeast and a few signs of alcohol. Complex flavor of roasted malt, overripe plums, figs, dates, caramel, yeast and hops. Finished sweet and full. Towards the end I had warming alcohol to finish the experience. Very good!

On tap at the Porter. Pours a dark red with a minimal head. The aroma is pleasant and complex. Notes of bread, cherries, nuts, dates and caramel. The flavor is a mixture of typical quadrupel nutty sweetness and a sour citrus flavor more akin to a witbier. It has a very light body for a quadrupel and finishes very smoothly. A strange and delicious beer.

tap at Barcade Allagash event - hazy, blood red pour. fresh caramel malts, fruity cherries and apples and a touch of tart arouma isn;t strong, but flavorfull candy and cherries. this one put me over for the night.

Bottle, batch # 19.  Aroma is sweet and a little syrupie.  Notes of citrus, darkfruit, honey, carmel, hops, and bread stand out.  The palate is a little chewey.  Flavor brings out an alcohol pressence and a bit of banana.

2007 bottle opened in 9/2010. Nose is not too strong, mild spice, mostly just caramel. Taste has serious depth, big caramel backbone, mellow yeast profile, perfect amount of residual sweetness, mildly fruity. dark fruits, virtually no alcohol heat. one of the better allagash beers ive had.

Poured into a couple of chalices it produced a good two fingers of a off white head that turned into a great lace. The body of the brew was amber/brown in color. The aromas of dark fruits and cherries along with some Belgian yeast filled my head.

The flavor followed the nose, fruity and yeasty. I did detect a little alcohol warmth as well, but it did not detract anything from the flavor. It had a medium to full feel to its body, with good carbonation. 

For a quad I will say that it was tasty enough to grab a second glass. The flavor was more than enough to accompany a fine cigar for desert. I often grab this brew when I am in the mood for a fine American Quad. I believe this one is the finest brewed on this side of the pond
dark and beery with alcohol spice and dried fruits. candylike and thick with a complex hop charactr that is superior in my mind. carbonation gets thru to keep it beery. nice

Dark amber/cider color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, yeast, dark fruit, & caramel; Flavor of sweet malt, yeast, caramel, dark fruit (notably plums), raisons, hops, and spice; Some alcohol at the finish; Nicely balanced and complex; Overall, a solid quad.
On tap at Allagash tasting at Stags Head.  Pours an amber brown.  taste is slightly syrupy and of candy sugar, roasted malt, figs, caramel, some yeast with a slight alcohol burn.  pretty good

Faint aroma of candi sugar and overripe apple. Murky copper,thick yellow head, minimal lacing. Metallic and relatively non descript flavor. There is a tartness, reminiscent of persimmon in quality but not in intensity. Woody finish. Very little flavor at fridge temperature, but at room temperature, subtle apple and cinnamon notes do appear. Full bodied with alcohol present, but somewhatt in the background. Suprisingly lackluster for the style, with little flavor. I can think of hundreds of beers better than this that are much more affordable. Ill have to check my ratings, but this may be the tamest quad Ive ever had.

Hazy to unclear amber with a medium beige head. Sweet aroma with roasted malt, caramel, dark overripe fruits, yeast and a few signs of alcohol. Flavor had roasted malt, overripe plums, figs, dates, caramel, yeast and hops. Finished sweet and full. Towards the end I had warming alcohol to finish the experience.
Bottle poured a reddish brown.  It was super carbonated with flavors of sweet malt and fruit help up with a hoppy backbone.

Beautiful Light Brown/Dark Copper tones.

That of citrus, Lemon/Orange Peel

Wow- not like it smells at all. A grapefruit. Medium Hops. Slightly sweet maple sugar. 

Over the top. Wonderful mouthfeel - one of the best Ive had. A major factor in my liking of this beer.

A sipper not a session beer. Allagash has done it again - another great addition to a stellar collection.
Pours slightly hazy dark amber with a nice tan head, and good lace ; Aroma of sweet malt and dried fruit ; Flavour is sweet malt, figs and caramel, with noticeable alcohol ; Lingering aftertaste

.750->Trappist: Pours a foamy brown, diminishing head atop a cloudy, amber body.  Aroma of yeast and sweetness.  Clean on the palate, medium bodied, being moderately sweet and finishing astringently.  A very nice high alcohol concoction.

Bottle. Clear red/amber pour with a big tan head. Aroma of caramel, wine and lots of dark fruit with Belgian esters. Caramel flavor with fruity esters and a bit of hop before a dank fruity finish. Nice.

On tap at downtown johnny browns. Pours a murky brown with small white head. Aroma of caramel malts and dark fruits. Mouthfeel is thick with moderate carbonation. Taste is sweet and malty with very little hop presence.
on tab at uber tavern june 11 2010. 6oz pour, very nice with a delicate and nice balance.

750ml bottle: Batch 20. Poured a beautiful, opaque, dark amber with a small, fizzy, off-white head. Aroma: caramel  malts, booze, yeast, notes of fruit & pepper. Taste: caramel malts, pepper, mild fruit, yeast, mild booze, all over a hoppy backbone. Full body, nice depth, good balance. Mild alcohol warming in the finish and a little dry. Mouth feel is almost syrupy (but not sticky). Overall: excellent - really enjoyed this Quad.

This beer is pretty tasty, and its from a style I dont tend to get that excited about.  Aroma is caramel, molasses, and dark fruit.   Color is a dark amber with a good head, tight lacing.  Taste is floral, cereal, nuts, caramel, and bourbony.  Palate is rich and creamy.  Pretty decent beer, but I am not sure its worth price tag for my taste.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2011 Rerate on 7/22/2011.  The aroma is fruity, cereal grains, yeasty, peppery. The appearance is lightly hazy deep amber, white head. The flavor is yeasty, peppery fruity, bready, enjoyable.   The finish is spicy, peppery, floral and citrus hops. Medium in body, slightly on the thick side.  Decent quad overall.

Draught at Rattle n Hum. Dark brown with light haze, small white head. Aroma is sweet molasses boozy with big booze spice, not very strong. Taste is sweet caramel booze with light spice. Oily on tongue but going dry in finish. Good, but i expected more.

Pours deep amber with off white head, aroma is bread, caramel, perfume, toffee, and nuts.  Taste up front is complex caramel and toffee, leading into some butterscotch, perfume, nuts, even a hint of apple that finishes creamy and sweet.
Bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  The look is clear, copper in color, and has an off white head.  The smell is very belgian, sweet, yeast, and fruits.  The taste is sweet, fruits, caramel, and yeast.
On draught at Chappys Taproom in Dayton, OH.  Poured an amber hazy color.  Aroma of apple/spice.  Tons of flavor and high alcohol content. Best beer I had on the night.  Highly recommended.

Bottled at Monks Café Wallingatan, Stockholm.  Lightly hazy copper colour, small head. Vinous and highly caramelly. Sweet and full bodied with clean, dense, rounded mouthfeel. Warming, brady and toffeeish with notes of cherry brandy and white pepper. Gets a bit syrupy and thick. The sweetness is more evident here than in most Belgian examples, making it less attractive.

Four Ale Belgian Style Quadruple--4 Malts--4 Hops--Fermented 4 Times--2005 25.4 oz. Bottle.  10.00% ABV.  25 IBUs?  (4.25 / 5.0)  Belgian Ale--Quadruple.  2 @ $12.99 Each.  Thin off white mild lace head.  Cloudy bright rich amber color.  Sweet apple hop front.  Crisp sweet malty Belgian candy fruit caramel body.  Clean hot EtOH mild hop rich end.  Sediment mellows overwhelming huge flavorful brew.  Sampled 1/1/2009.

Though we have Allagash available in Pittsburgh...their more special brews are hard to come by. I picked this up at Stateline in MD. Review #400. Poured into my Mad Elf Chalice- I am drinking this as I review it.

A- Translucent Mahogany body that pours with a 2 finger creamy off-white head. Head fades to a thick collar and retains well but very little lacing is left behind in the glass. When held up to the light one can see that the cloudiness is thick and uniform and the red hues shine a bit more.

S- Belgian candi sugar, molasses, dark fruits (perhaps raisin), and dates hit the nose first-all pretty well balanced. Behind this is a faint spiciness and a looming smell of alcohol. The nose is very complex, but is very mild overall. Nothing is overpowering.

T-The flavor is much like the smell. Upfront are candi sugars, dates, dark fruits, and molasses all with pretty equal strength. Behind this is a complex malt and yeast combination that can be tasted more if you let the sip linger in your mouth (chocolate and toffee come through as well as a sweet bready flavor). A nice touch of spicy hop flavor is added to the finish and this is where the alcohol has a slight bite. Left to linger is something that resembles a vanilla creaminess, a touch of spicy hop flavor, a mild alcohol bitterness, and faint remnants of everything else. The character of this brew if very complex yet somewhat mild.

P-A medium, but ever tingly carbonation and a body rich in yeast. Extraordinarily smooth and creamy.

O- This is a very nice Quad. Very complex and somewhat mild...there are flavors here that are much more complex than my palate. This is what I imagine a great Quad to be. The alcohol is there...but it is much milder than in other examples of this style I have tried. Probably my favorite from Allagash so far...I will pick this up again.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-04-2008 00:05:39

Picked up at Whole Foods in Columbus Circle.  Fabulous beer.  My first Allagash.  Pours a cloudy brownish orange with a beautiful frothy off-white head.  Aroma is so malty it just tickles the nose.   Taste is a pleasure.  Malts play on the palate and the hops bite.  There is alcohol taste in the undertones but it borders on a whiskey feel to the palate that is awesome.  Ill look for it again.

2008 Bottle served into a Belgian Tulip glass. Cloudy Brown color, very murky looking with a frothy thick head. Picking up orange peel in the aroma with some alcohol tones that remind me of rum. More orange flavors, with some earthy malt characteristics. Alcohol presence definitely noted in the taste.  Well carbonated, full bodied. Big alcohol finish lingers on for a bit. Very nice sipping beer if you can look past the predominant alcohol flavors. Might even consider aging this beer longer.

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy deep amber color with a small off-white head. Has a malty caramel and floral hoppy aroma with hints of candi sugar. Sweetish malty caramel flavor with hints of hops and yeast. Has a sweetish malty yeasty finish with hints of hops in the aftertaste and also some alcoholic hints.

bottle.  Pours a reddish brown with a huge tan head.  Nose is of brown sugar and malt.  Taste is big on brown sugar.  Mouthfeel is sweet, almost cloying and slightly bitter.  This was way overpriced for what it delivers.  Disappointed.

Aroma could be described as candy sugar (not candi sugar)  interlaced with a caramel malt.  It will hit your mouth from the full bottle sample, not the 1.8 oz. sample, as a beer, but will identify a malt laced with a lab added sugar (sucrose, not dextrose), the middle holds approximately 99.7% of the malt where the "majickal" process of trans-ementaltranslucification occurs where little merry blue men take your tongue for a ride off the 1.7 oz. side, off to where Obama says its ALL GOOD... and then it takes you to where your seat feels like a giant marshmellow, and then you are loved by everyone, and then...THEN...(cough cough)... sorry, the joke is on you, not me.  (HEAVILY CENSORED- for those that speak Russian).  My Jan. purchase sipped in April- price- $17.99 USD,  Worth it?  Nyet.

On tap at Battleship Brewhouse.  Pours a deep hazy amber color.  Aroma is of malts, floral, and some hops.  Flavor is full of malts, with some citrus, floral, and a little bitterness.  Leaves a malt finish.

Cask @ 2010 ATL Cask Ale Tasting.  Poured a hazy amber with a thin egg shell head.  Slightly boozy, vinous nose with notes of caramel, floral hops, and candi sugar.  Medium body with a creamy mouth feel.  Flavor is mostly sweet with big fruity notes of fig, plum, and raisin, there also some secondary notes of chocolate and spice present.  Finishes sweet with the chocolate notes even more present.

Bottle. Dark auburn with thick creamy foam, like ice cream head and lots of lace. Aroma is jammy, strawberry jam. Sweet smelling. Silky soft palate. Nice body but wow--this one is very sweet! Too sweet for me. Can tell its a well-made beer but is just so jammy. I might prefer this with age on it.

Pours a semi-translucent honey golden with a thick, fine-bubbled, pale yellow-cream head. Aroma is fruity, yeasty and slightly sweet. Richly fruity flavor has hints of yeast, malt and honey - quite tasty. Lively, tingly, fizzy, sassy texture leaves a nice honey-sweet but not cloying finish.

Cask. Appearance is orangish amber, with a smal off-whte head.  Nose is lightly fruity, caramely sweet, and light hopped.  Taste is is similar, with the sweetness and fruitiness dominating.  Hop bitterness in the finish.  Cask conditioning is pretty nice, soft carbonation.  Overall, a decent brew that is nice on cask.

Draft at Birreria Paradiso.  Thick brown-amber color.  Mellow CO2, big flavor.  Super malt depth, some pungent raisin and fig.  Slight alcohol warmth wont go unnoticed.  A little lacking in effervescence compared to the bottle, which I remember enjoying much more.  Rating only reflects the draft version sampled.

Bottle at T&Ms from Drewbeerme THX!. Pours a slightly hazy brown. Smells of chestnuts and hitns of alcohol. Sweet with malty aromas of nuts and and some caramel. Tiny hints of nuts. Some fruity notes. Medium to full bodied. Beginning to be over the top but still really good.
Bottle (Thanks Sune) shared with sune & Mette. Clear amber - white head. Nutty, oxidation, dusty, roasted, sweetness, dark sugar, green walnuts, light oldness signs, vinous, light alcoholic,
bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  deep amber with a cream head.  alcohol, malts, yeast and dried fruits on the nose.  thick on the palate with heavy dried fruits, yeast and alcohol for the flavor.

On tap at Sunset Grill. A nice fine quad to help you stumble from your bar stool. Tan colored with little head, nice lacing. Mildly sweet with a tad of bitterness. I cant really pull out any individual aromas. Everything blended together well. Nice job.

Bottle thanks to thirdeye11. Pours a nice hazy amber with off-white head. Aroma of nice hop, malt and fruit. Flavor has some nice sweetness and fruitiness, a bit of caramel and a touch of dark fruit. Mouth feel is medium-heavy body with medium-high carbonation. Overall, very tasty!

(750ml bottle via trade with BA Ding marked batch 19) Pours clear brown with nice head and lacing. Nose of raisins, Belgian yeast, and figs. Taste of yeast, raisins, light chocolate and biscuit. Fruity well carbonated finish.
Bottle thanks to thirdeye11. Pours a dark reddish brown color with a medium sized tope colored foamy head. Notes of raisins, soy, and green grapes. Medium finish.
Bottle thanks to thirdeye11. Hazy orange pour with small tan head. Aroma is caramel, clove. Flavor is clove, caramel, bread, bitter and some pine. Fizzy mouth.

Bottle courtesy of thirdeye11. Clear dark orange color. Fuzzy off white color on the head. Light grape juice aroma. Easy grains with fruit. Big yeast flavor with light fruit and dry bitterness. Finishes easy with some smooth malts. Not bad.
bottle, thanks to thirdeye11, dark reddish brown, aromas of funky sour cherry, flavors of sweet belgian fruit, toffee, apricots, raisin
Cask ale festival. Big beer, malty sweetness, lots of brown sugar, molasses, touch of banana flavors.  Alcohol fairly present. Not bad, but couldnt drink a ton of it.

cloudy deep purpl color, looks like prune juice. Aroma entails the sweet smell of wild cherries and plum, flavor is a very creamy, carmel malt with a little cherry acidity. Lots of thick dark fruits. Deliscious. Bottle at Knightly Spirits, Orlando.

Cask @ ATL Cask Fest. Pours deep brown red. Nose is candy sugars, earthy malts, mild roast, alcohol and fruit esters. Flavor is sweet malts, belgian yeast, subtle spice, hints of roast, cherries, alcohol and herbs.

Out of the bottle.  Deep red with gold tinges and an amazing big lacy head, slightly hazy. Malts jump out of the glass with loads of biscuit and bread. The alcohol rears its head on the nose. Full mouthfeel that balances well with the taste. Great well balanced taste with biscuit, candied sugar and a surprisingly dry finish.
This is a full bodied beer.  Big amount of malt and some toasty notes snuck in at the end of it.  Getting a little sweetness as well.

Pours a medium-dark brown with a huge, fluffy white head. The beer is a little hazy and is not see-through. A great looking beer.

Smell is dark fruits, lots of raisins and some Belgian yeast.

The taste has some dark fruits, as well as some caramel malt and some sweetness which I guess is from the candi sugar. I dont get any alcohol in the flavor. It cant be easy to hide all the alcohol flavor and aroma in a 10 percent beer, but Allagash has pulled it off. The beer does give you a warming sensation in your chest, absolutely wonderful.

As large as the head was, the beer is not that carbonated which I really appreciate. The beer is not that thick in the mouthfeel, making it easy to drink. At 10 percent, this is very drinkable and could be dangerous since you cant taste any of the alcohol. A great beer.
Lovely fruit filled nose. Can tell that hops and malts are in harmony from the first smell. Fruit flavors are a bit tart though. Tasty stuff.

Sampled at Barrios Sausage Fest 2010!  Pours a hazy orange with ring of tan head.  Nose of vanilla yogurt, raisins, candi sugar, mild alcohol esters.  Flavor is very similar, but a little syrupy, and hides the alcohol amazingly well.  Very good.

Pours a clear amber with slight white head.  Very sugary sweet, hoppy, yeasty, malty flavor.  Very complex aroma.  Taste is very sweet but very well balanced by the abundance of hops and malts. Very  sticky. Interesting beer.
Pours a lacing beige head with a copper-ruby body.  Aromas of pineapple, mango, and bubblegum.  Flavors of dried fruit, citrus hops, red wine, dough.  Finish is sticky and dry.

Dark amber in color... Aroma of candi sugar and alcohol... Flavor is sweet of candi sugar but not terribly complex... Alcohol content is noticeable but the sweetness helps conceal it... Decent but not the best for its genre

Golden color with a tiny white head that disappears rapidly to leave scant bubbles and great lacing.
Aroma of freshly rising bread dough.
Flavor begins with orange peel and coriander, progresses to a nice sourness and finishing with a bitter tone.
Great body, almost chewy.
A wonderful brew, especially on cask.
Very nice balance of alcohol, malts, and hops.  This beer hits a good Belgain Abbey blonde.  Nice orange, citruis, and bittering hops.  Yeast flavors are like a heffeweizen.
Pours a copper amber color, nice white head.  A sweet yeast aroma.  Flavor is a lot of malt with a very distinct bitterness.  This beer isnt overly yeasty, strikes a good balance with the malts.
0.75l - Red/orange liquid, no head, sour nose.  Butterscotch on the palate, liked it better as it warmed.  Not a miss but not a hit either.
6th July 2008. Smooth malty beer - no bitterness at all. Very dry aromatic finish. Not a bad Belgian style beer but otherwise unremarkable.

09 bottle thanks to KGAGNE (BA)!Hazy copper-tea color, light beige bubbly head. Nose has light alcohol, light sugar and dried fruit, a hint of overly-sweet honey, and dusty wood, like a Builder Square lumber aisle. Sugary flavor, still bearing the Allagash yeast mark. Sticky, lightly alcoholic, lots of date and apple throughout the flavor. Decent but not entirely impressive.
draft: cloudy dark amber, clove and banana aroma, spicy taste with some citrus, fairly carbonated

Sampled at Flying Saucers Second Annual Fall Beer Festival in Austin on October 24, 2009.  Cloudy amber orange with thin soapy head.  Spiced aroma.  Light bitter flavor and a little numbing on the tongue.  Silky alcoholic mouthfeel, sweet finish. Very clean and not over-sweetened.

750 batch 15 poured a brown amber in color with a pillow of light tan head and nice carbonation cracking at the surface. aroma has dark rich fruit, Belgian yeast, nutmeg, anise, raisin, and some sweet caramel. medium mouth feel with low side carbonation and a nice coating. flavor opens with a dark fruit medley, hearty Belgian yeast, caramel sweetness, dark malt, and some alcohol warming. nice and smooth on the flavors while coming off rich and hearty.

Bottle @ tasting by jbrus. A clear dark amber colored beer, with a little beige head. The aroma is fruity, raisin and peaches. There are flavors of hop. The taste is sweet from apples with peaches. It burns and its sticky. In the back spices like cinnamon. The aftertaste is sweet and fruit bitter.

From bottle. Sweet malt aroma, weetibix cereal in the glass. Cloudy muddy, treacle cloudy amber colour. Very rich and fruity flavour with malt. Slightly bitter hops. Complex fruit flavours, plum, pears maybe. All delicious. Just didnt hit the spot really. A little to much rich syrup and nothing exciting.
