Dark mahogany with a medium ivory head that leaves lots of lace as it recedes. Nose: candi sugar, spices and yeast. Flavor: dark fruits, peaches, cinnamon, hazelnuts and just a hint of chocolate. Smooth, creamy mouthfeel. The 10% ABV is well hidden. Nice.

Wow.Number 200 for me.This beer pours a dark amber with a thick fluffy head.The head dissipates while drinking, but stays laced on the top and clinging to the sides of the glass.Heavy fruit and nut flavors.The alcohol is present but not overpowering.Some spiciness going down with some bitterness as the finish.

Pours a bright hazy reddish-orange color with a nice off-white head that leaves a sticky lacing in my glass. Sweet fruity aromas, flavors of plums, cherries and spicy pepper. Full bodied with a smooth and creamy mouthfeel, alcohol well hidden, finishes a bit sweet.

Dark red and brown coloring. The head is medium sized and a yellowish tan. The aroma is yams, cloves, peaches and bread. The taste is sweet and the mouthfeel is full bodied. Also a sticky feel in the mouth. The tastes also have brandy, yams and a spicy finish. The finish is cloves. A very nice and solid brew with the alcohol well hidden.

Copper colored brew raising a thick off cream colored head. A little to much alcohol in the nose for my liking but thankfully it doesnt come through in the taste. Malty, fruity, spicy and just a little sweetness. Very enjoyable.

Sampled at the DC/MD/VA/WV/PA Ratebeer Gathering 11/20/04. Pours a clear amber with an off white head. Great malty, fruity aroma with some yeast. Taste has notes of chocolate, candi sugar, dark fruits, spiciness and earth. Very complex. Full and round on the palate. Awesome quad.
Bottle..light copper color w.small white head.  Aroma fruity,candisugary,..taste is pretty smooth with a dry somewhat spicy finish,,alc is subdued nicely.good

Tap. Nice hazy amber color with medium sized head poured into a nice Allagash glass. Aroma has a nice yeast smell. The 1stthing about drinking this I noticed was how lively the mouthfeel is. The taste has flavors of dark fruits and an excellent yeast strain. Somewhat bitter and very smooth.

Bottle: Orangy deep amber hue with a LONG lasting head and very good lace. The aroma has notes of fruits (orange zest, banana, and pear), clove and pepper, aromatic hops, earthy yeast and noticeable phenols. The taste starts quite fruity (lots of banana tones) and malty but then a twangy and earthy nature (Green Tea and rosemary) adds quite the twist to the palate. The alcohol levels keep the palate from becoming sensory overwhelmed. The finish as a dry bark and bitter bite just to keep you honest and wanting more. This brew shcoked me by how good it was. The best American version of an Abt, sure I would say so. I want more!

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2006 Clear coppery orange. White frothed head yields intricately webby lacework. Medicinal, clove, and phenolic esters in the aroma. Hint of raisins, rum, vibrant hoppiness, and damp tea leaves. Abundant yeast yields notes of passionfruit and plantain. Fluffily creamy, densely spongy carbonation. Sharp alcohol tingles the sides of the cheeks, but is softened by a soft fusion of flowers, bananas, and savory yeast decadence, which thickens the body and blankets the tongue. Soft, but highly explosive juicy hops. Lush display of banana and belgian yeast nuanced with clove-spiced cake. Very vague, but noticeable,  candy sugar impression. Has a voluptuously  malty, yeasty smoothness to the body, but theres an overexerted metallic zip that lessens the overall richness. Chalky dryness increases as it reaches room temp. Juggling display of bready malts gel with a caramel and coconut essence drizzle, which revitalizes the delicate passionfruit and rounded  peach  acidity. Gorgeously yeasty aroma and flavor, and packed with a full assortment of mind-boggling subtleties, although the candy sugar remnants were a tad too apparent. Quite hoppy aroma, to boot. A tad sweet and overspiced, but pretty nice.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text:
Hazy, pale orange he, nestled under a neat creamy white head, thin, but steady...aroma? nicely spicy and citric, intriquing and utterly lovely, ...lets go in once again...yeast is prominent, too, and I anticipate its acitvity in the flavor, as well, so lets taste away...
Big, beautiful mouthfeel, huge presence in the palate, wondrously fresh and delicious and spilling over with fruity, spicy flavor...yum, yum...yeast is big, again, floats right on top, and delivers delciousness. Hey, I like this one, I like plenty! Full-bodied, long, persistent, ever-present finish, lush mouthfeel. Every new sip brings fresh zesty, buoyant taste.
I really cant recommend this highly enough...Ive said "yum" already, what more you need to know?
(750ml Bottle)  Pours a cloudy amber-brown body with a small beige head.  Aroma of malt, hops, and spices.  Dry and creamy palate.

Aroma:  spicy bananas, bubble gum, grapes, bit of hops and malts

Appearance:  murky brown, large creamy head, lacing

Flavor:  carmel, malts, some spicy bananas, light pears

Palate:  very smooth, slight alcohol taste but not bad, light carmel aftertaste, frothy (like a latte when first prepared)

Overall:  a very balanced beer

Large frothy head of light tan color with a foamy, small-bubbled texture.  The aroma is strong and sweet, with multiple apple aromas, some pear, sugary bubble gum, and light alcohol presence.  Semi-thick up front, thickening as it rolls over the tongue.  From the aroma I was expecting something sweet, like Karmeliet, but its much more balanced and central, similar to a New Belgium Trippel.  Sweet caramelized apples, pears, some light orange as well; light alcohol presense as well, just as in the nose.  A little tart at times, and it warms the stomach as a light residue coats the mouth.  Overall quite good, but lacking the depth that I was expecting.

Beautiful in the glass, nice dark copper brown with a thick and creamy head on top. Aroma of candi sugar, yeast, and peach.  Very nicely balanced flavor, nothing overwhelms or pushes its way to the front, nice spicy finish. Great mouthfeel. Thanks to matta for this one!

aPRIL 2004.  Beautiful brown ale with a thick off-white head. Nice fruity aroma with peaches and yeast . Warm alcohol mouthfeel with licorice, spices, herbs. Very complex but not as much as Achel Extra.

I had only a bit of this beer at a beer tasting, but was very impressed.  It was easily my favorite Allagash at the table.  My ratings are most likely a bit off due to my limited exposure to it, but I will plan on picking up a bottle and re-rating soon.

Hazy amber colour body with a dense tan head. Aroma of caramel, hops, cardboard and fruits. Light-bodied; Sweet flavour withi malt and raisins coming through big-time. Aftertaste shows some clean tastes with caramel flavours throughout. Overall, great to try-thanks to Tim for bringing this! I sampled this 75 cL bottle on 15-May-2004 at the May RB Party in Toronto, Ontario.
redish brown, amber like color, complemented by thin white head; a flowery sweet scent; explosion of flavors (fruits and sugars galore); nice long aftertaste

Rating #800.Hazy orange-red body, thin off-white head dissipating to a faint ring of carbonation.  Theres lots of stuff in this beer but the aroma and palate are only moderately complex, with apple, candi sugar, and brown sugar characterizing both.  There are hints of cinnamon and clove that complement the apple and sugars.  Finishes slightly leathery and with an alcohol bite.  Under the sugary bliss some vinous notes take hold.  A solid Quad but not a standout.  Have I really come this far?

Thick amber hue with a thin, but lasting, off-white head. Sweet, fresh nose. Very lively carbonation with spikes on the tongue. As it warmed, the base thickened nicely. Big pepper throughout. Some clove and salt as well. Lesser notes of apples, grape skins and toast. Sweetness is very subtle, almost too subtle. Bitterness is moderate and relatively balanced. Finishes dry and warm. Overall, I thought it was well made and very pleasant to drink, but it wasnt as complex as Id hoped ... especially with the touted three fours.

Poured ruby amber in color with thin tan head...caramel, mild hops, alcohol, malty sweetness in the nose...beautiful mouthfeel...light fruits (apples, pears) some nuts and some bread with a sweet tartness on the sides of the tongue...finish is a little alcoholic, but ever so smooth...goodness indeed...$12.49 makes it a little over priced, but Im going to pick up another bottle to lay it down...I bet this one is going to age fantastically!

Tangerine.

Deep dark cherries, ripe plums, toasted and caramel malt in the nose.

I am amazed at how simply drinkable and deceiving this beer really is. The 10% tastes like 6. Banana, clove, spiced out yeast, dried dark fruits, ripe fruits, pear and just a hint of coriander. This is very similar to another world classic, Bush beer, with its hefty huge mouthfeel and its dangerous drinkability. 

A winner.

Reminded me of a classic Unibroue yeasty ale - so of course I enjoyed it. But I think I was expecting something different that what I got - it was a cloudy cooprey brown with an off-white froth. Lots of malt and yeast and spices on the nose and then a somewhat sweet flavour of varied elements (Nutmeg?, Caramel?, ??). In the end I thought it lingered too harshly and showed the alcohol that the 4 fermentations wrought a little too plainly. Perhaps it would age a bit better? Cheers to joey_capps though - it was enjoyable overall.

750 mL, corked & caged: thin, milky taupe coloured film rests on top of a beautiful rose bodynutmeg, orange zest, spicy almonds, bitter honey, and doughnuts dominate a fresh and bold aroma.  Smooth palate that has nice Belgian qualities: strong, fruity yeast and soothing alcoholic malts.  Spicy dough flavours, laced with pepper, apricots, flower petals and perfume.  A solid quad, but doesnt quite have the complexities of some of Trappists

Wow, really exciting on the tounge. It just kinda explodes with tiny little bubbels mixed with wonder malt sweetness and dark fruits. Poured a deep brown cloudy orange. The mouthfeel alone makes this one a winner. I cant wait to lay a few down, though I wont be laying too many at the cost of $12!!

Beer pours (in Westmalle glass) a cloudy brown-red liquid with a small amount of light beige head that dissipates quickly to near nothing.  Aroma is of fresh, sweet fruit, berries, very pleasant.  Flavor is of fresh, sour apples/ pears.  The carbonation is very bubbly and stings the mouth.  Pleasant, but somewhat watery mouthfeel.

Nice presentation. Good foam and soft carmel color. Some candi sugar and cookie flavors. Significant hop flavors citric and grapefruit. Some melon and light raisin. A creamy feel even as t warms. I was hoping for more as the beer warmed but my patience was left unrewarded. Remarkable but for a $10 bottle of beer, I think maybe next time Id let it age and cross my fingers.

Big fuzzy head on top of a slightly murky amber body.  The aroma is mouthwatering; full of yeast and spice that just begs for a sip.  Flavor lives up to the nose, and is lovely.  Everything is in there to play with.  The Belgian yeast, sticky malt, sugars, and hints of hops just swirl around and make for one fantastic beer.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2007 Pours a clear amber color with a thin offwhite head. Aroma of alcohol, spices, malt and leather. Good flavor of spices, malt, leather and yeast, the belgian character is well present and interesting. The body is medium with a creamy texture and moderate carbonation. Good stuff.
Rich Dark Amber Coloring. Big Head.  Didnt Have As Much Bang As I Was Expecting, But Still Very Enjoyable.  Very Sweet.  Malts and Hops Detectable But Subdued.  Some Fruit.
Lite amber considering the style. Nice aromas of vanilla, yeasty breadiness, spices and a ton o malt. Very drinkable for the strength. One of the better American-Belgian ales Ive had.

Brownish color, very murky, with a giant head.  Sweet and spicy aroma.  The taste was a bit of a letdown.  Fruit and grains are present, but not in a big enough fashion to really stand out.  Good, but not as good as I was hoping.

Classic Belgian fruity-plum aroma, some grainy cereal-like malt, light clove spiciness.  Hazy brown, thin white head.  Fruity, spicy malt flavors, definitely some alcohol.  Medium-bodied and warming.  A simple, somewhat alcoholic Belgian-style beer.

A dark fruit aroma with spice, clove and fig.  There is a great alcohol to residual sugar balance.  Flavor contains lots of residual sugar (almost cane-like or crystallized).  There is also an orangey fruit flavor with cinnamon and notes of tea with cream.  A great beer to lay down.  There seems to be a lot of potential for aging but for right now it is a little too sweet for me (even when comparing it against other Quads).

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2004 Another excellent brew by the folks at Allagash.  Pours brown with a medium-sized head and a sweet aroma. Flavor is malty, a little chocolatey, and alcoholic.  Not quite as good as their Tripel, but great if you can find it.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2004 Bottle at blind tiger. Deep brown, cloudy, no head at all. Nose is hit up by bready malt and yeast flavors. Rather sweet aroma: fruity (grapes, melon, dates) with mild vanilla-like alcohol vapors. Musty peaks. On the tongue, the big allagash malt hits you up. Caramelic, chocolatey, marzipan-like, very sweet. Easy to pick up alcohol, but its an ABT and you dont mind that. Decent flavor balance, but just not as appealing fruitiness or yeastiness than top examples who are probably just as sweet, but manage to stuck your mind out of this thought. Full body, high carbonation a la allagash, smooth anyway. I found their tripel vastly superior, but allagash knows their brewing, no doubts about it and this will be highly enjoyable in a few years. Resampling proposed a far yeastier sample with less flavorful malt and a much more subdued flavor profile. Notes of white chocolate, sweet honey, flowers... Lowering from 3.8 to 3.5

Murky brown color,small head that had a short life then faded leaving little behind.nice fruity sweet aroma with a slight spicy hint.Nice fruit flavor the carbonation seems to make the flavors dance on the tongue with a decent hop presenceThe alcohol stays pretty well hidden with just a hint towards the end and a slight warming effect going down.Very nice brew and thanks go to Shadey for sending this very nice brew my way.

Neutral fruits, Belgian yeast, malty. Toast, light ozone hops. A subtle nose. Dark reddish amber clearxwith thin lacing off-white head. Medium silky body with smooth active carbonation. Starts with malty sweetness, vanilla, Belgian yeast. Alcohol, light fruity tang. Malty throughout with drying hop finish. Warming, light bitter sweet after. Nutty. Really nice ale.
Fresh and fruity, yet cellary. Reddish brown with a creamy head. Fruity chocolate flavour. Smooth, solid, very nice, but ultimately too sweet. A bit like brown sugar, really - very sweet.

Bottle pours a cloudy deep amber, medium off-white fluffy head, strong carbonation, with attractive lacing.   Dark pitted fruit (albeit light), cloves, and hints of candi sugar on the nose.   Earth, cloves, and a hint of fig/date on the tongue.   A bit sour too...   Full bodied, enjoyable mouthfeel.   Finishes just as it starts, earthy, spices, and some dark pitted fruit.   This one isnt as sweet as I would have liked, but is still quite enjoyable.   10% ABV is well hidden, albeit quite warming.   Thanks goes out to The_Beer_God for the trade!

75cL bottle.  Excellent beer!  I was looking forward to finally tasting this beer...thanks to Humulone Red for sharing!!!  It had a great, big Belgian yeast flavor and aroma.  The carbonation was fantastic and allowed the flavors and aromas to fill your senses.  I think it had a bit of coriander in it, too.  If you can find this beer, try it.

I have been waiting to taste this one for a while.  POurs a deep amber with a slight off-white head.  Aromas of hops and pears and flavors of caramel and yeast.   Full bodied but with a slight tang on the palate.  I will try again, but for now, it is my least favorite Quadruple ale, but still decent overall.
Murky light cherry red in hue.  Some head with great lacing. Spicy/malty nose.  Great sweet spicy and yeasty character.  It has a creamy sweet finish.   What a great beer!

08.01.04  750ml bottle.  Pours a clouded red/orange/amber that glows in the glass; smallish, creamy head; slight lacing.  Smells yeasty, lots of alcohol, some light fruitiness, but really not any huge aromas in my Chimay goblet considering this is a quad.  Maybe a tulip wouldve been better?  Flavors of sweet plum, brown sugar, banana, slightly tropical.  Palate is outstanding - creamy, smooth, and coating, then *BANG* hops come in for an unusual finish that is sharp and somewhat biting.  Quite well done quad.  Its definitely done in an American style that exaggerates sweetness and bitterness.   Unusual and wonderful to ponder.

Pours a nice dark red with a tall off-white head. Spicy aroma, wheaty and caramel sweetness. Taste starts sweet with a good fizziness and ends with a nice balanced bitterness. Good spice to it with some smooth maltiness and a slightly acidic end.

Nice auburn color with a tan film of head & light lacing. The aroma is very full and fruity with yeast & candi sugar. Lots of carbonation with tangy yeast & carbonation. Finishes sweet, tangy, long tail.

Sugary sweet aroma with a little banana and yeast.  Color is a deep copper brown color but suprisingly clear,  Large chunky, foamy head.  Taste is very sweet in the front.  Middle is a little bland and flat and the finich is acidic.  I do not know if this will get better with age, I hope so.  This is a great brewery and I think they can do better than this.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, off-white, mostly lasting. Body is hazy light brown, bottle conditioned. 
Aroma is lightly malty (cookie, caramel), moderately yeasty (cobwebs, mold), with a note of clove. Flavor is 
moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter. 
Medium to full body, velvety texture, lively carbonation. Surprisingly simple and overly yeasty.  Good flavor balance and mouthfeel, but otherwise not nearly as good as I expected/hoped.

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2004 Rating #900.   I suppose that this is a well made beer, but the bottom line for me is that it really doesnt taste all that good.  I am giving it a 5, with a benefit of doubt; since I believe it to be made to a style ie. "American Belgian."  At least that is what I call it.  Because no great Belgian beers actually taste like this.   This beer is hot.  It has an unpleasant astringent quality that borders on offensive to me, but on the other hand I dont want to pour it out either.  So I am sticking to the middle for flavor and aroma.  It is a nice looking beer, and the mouthfeel can be called "velvety" which is good.  Bottom line  - if you like the style of beer that I call "American Belgian," you like that astringent heat, and you like Ommegang and Unibroue stuff - then you will love this beer.  Its not really my bag though.
candy apple color, really really bitter rubbery feel to it, not really as good as i thought from the aroma.

Somewhat fruity and yeasty aroma; fairly sweet and a bit spicey with a slightly sour and bitter finish. Nice.
Thanks Sham & Bück Dich!

Amber-red, small off white head. Citrus aromas. Some biscuit. Pear or apricot fruits. Citrus and bitter hops. Flavors are slightly sour with nice hops (bitter and citrus.) Some alcohol. Palate is malty, bitter, sour, and fuzzy.

A beer the keeps on giving! I was impressed. A slight singed grain nose, deep mahogany color, and a low tight head. Sweet malt with some honey and vanilla in the middle as well as corriander. Clovey end and a little pepper. Full body, rich and creamy. Fat. Just a well-done beer.

750 ml. big ole brown Belgian-style, corked and caged bottle. If there is or was a freshness date, I did not notice it. Beautiful gold printing over a brown glass bottle makes for a great design. I might have to add this bottle to my very limited collection. Poured out a deep amber/ medium caramel candy color, with a limited, although generous eggshell colored head. Deserves to be served in an appropriate glassware, so I served it in my Chimay chalice.
Outrageous aromas of malt, hops, and yeast. Brown sugar aromas come into view as this beer warms up slightly, as does Belgian candi sugars, and I believe I detect a note of Turbinado sugar as well. The hops aromas are somewhat subdued, but the flavors are evident in the tasting. The aromas and flavors mingle on the tongue, providing a flavor-fest in the mouth. Tastes are what youd expect from a huge Belgian beer. Malts, some slightly bitter hops, yeast, and sugars abound in the flavors of this beer. Mouthfeel is rich, thick, and full. More of a meal than a beer, per se. Slightly sweet on the tongue, but just barely bordering on cloying. I believe it needs about 5 more years of aging to come into its peak. Tastes are full of flavors which become hard to describe, because of the complexity of the beer itself. This beer is deceptively drinkable, because the alcohol is well hidden at this point. It may become more evident as it ages, but only time will tell. Finishes sweet, full bodied, and very rich. Im glad I bought 2 of these delicious monsters, as I will be able to age one for several years and I will compare notes with this tasting at that point in time. You owe it to yourself, if no one else, to seek out this beer at any and all costs. A terrific Belgian-style beer from the good old USA. Whouldve thought it? I certainly didnt.
mmmh - nice one. Burnt nose with some alcohol hints in it. Amber brown color, no head. Also burnt biter taste, with a medium aftertaste, light alcohol and a dry finish. Nice.
Translucent, decent sized head that dissipates slowly.  Metallic flavour while cold, goes away as beer warms up.
Another good Maine Beer. Allagash does something with their beer: Love it to death.

Deep brown and orange body with a dense head.  Yeasty aroma, giving up candi sugar and citrus, sweet hops and a little malt.  Flavor is candi sugar, alcool, bitter orange (peel?)  There is a long lasting sweet roasted malt/hop/candi finish.  Beautifully smooth and perfectly carbonated

Medium brown with a tan head.  Yeasty, fruity and malty nose.  Full-flavored - caramel, complex biscuity malts, raisins and other fruits, yeast all present.  Dry, flowery or grassy finish with little aftertaste.  Very nice, but not as unique as they make it out to be with respect to its flavor characteristics.

Brown/red with a large tan head. 
Very yeasty nose with touches of caramel, apricots. 
Musty, yeasty, medium sweet flavor with orange, apricots. Quite bitter finish.

Bottle, from Julios, Good nose, spice, clove, honey, toffee, ABV. Big head, reddish orange color. Sweet and sour flavors, Same as nose.  Creamy, but not thick, mouthfeel, kinda fruity dry finish. Ok, though mellower  than Id of guessed for a 10%  beer.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text:
MAssive head, very sweet, should be perfect with chocolate.
A nice desert beer.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2006 Beautiful two-inch light tan head atop a brilliant reddish copper body with suspended yeast particles.  Big, fruity nose of ripe apples, plum, cherries, raisins, chocolate, biscuits, light hops, dark candy sugar, yeasty, toasted bread, the occasional bubblegum phenols, and a touch of caramel.  The body is soft, supple and extremely elegant.  More luscious fruit in the flavor with a nice subdued sweetness.  The alcohol is warming, but not overpowering.  The hops provide a unique short, bitterness that I expect would mellow out with some time.  The finish is long and slightly sweet with that warming of the belly, that makes the mind happy.  Ultimately, another great Belgian from one of the best Belgian style brewers in the US of A.  I really hope this makes it to Chicago, as time will only help this gentle giant.  I dont know if it was time or what, but this was truly outstanding.A re-sampling of this beer showed that while this was a tasty beer, it wasnt as excellent as I had initially thought.  The experience was great, but the beer was merely great as well.
Big pillowing head. Spicy yeasty nose. Proper brisk Belgian carbonation. Dry and fruity. Complex. Little trace of alcohol.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2004 Allagashs versions of the Belgian styles succeed where other American attempts fail, and that is its ability to create a palate full enough to support the alcohol and fruit.  THere is alos a lot of hop spice and a bit of molasses in this one, as well.  Great balance, but I wish there were an element to it which made it memorable: I come away from tasting this thinking that Allagash did a great job duplicating the style, but didnt add anything to what has been done before.  Perhaps I am being too harsh.

Foggy copper color with a frothy tan head. Very malty. Some spice and yeasts. Dry in the palate. Very rich flavor. Sweet, some spices like cinnamon in the flavor. Caramel as well. Dry in the finisth. Pretty decent. Bought this bottle at Total Wine in Alexandria, VA.

Really dark copper brown color with a thick and nicely lacing off-white head.  Aroma is full of bready Belgian yeast and dark malts with a touch of molasses.  Starts rich, thick and sweet with a subtle musky spice.  Finishes sweet and smooth with milk chocolatey cookie notes.  Hides its alcohol very well. Another nice Allagash beer.  Thanks slob!

dark brown, thick head, almost exactly looking as Chimey Bleu. Hints of citrus, nuts and some outhose in the aroma. Taste is very sweet, smooth, somewhat fruity, with a yeasty finish with some nuts or raisins ... nice stuff

I was very excited to drink this since I had very high expectations, especially considering the $11 price tag. But, it was most certainly worth it. All the work that went into brewing this beer paid off tremendously. Absolutly smooth and delicious... everything blends together perfectly. There is a bit of warming, but the 10% alcohol suprised me since it is hidden so well. Yes, it is expensive as hell, but give it a shot. It is well worth it.

Engaging aroma, full of sweet malt and doughy, estery yeast with notes of turbinado sugar, banana, pineapple, tangerine, plum, clove, coriander, anise and faint, peppery alcohol.  Highly attractive deep, cloudy garnet color, topped with a lasting, voluminous, frothy off-white head and abundant lacing.  Flavor profile is similarly intriguing, beginning with a burst of lightly tart tropical fruitiness, turning spicy and toasty with a long, sweet, toffeeish and mildly grainy finish that eventually gives way to hints of milk chocolate.  Downy soft, effervescent palate with a deceptively full body.  Balance and complexity are both impressive in their depth.  I found it reminiscent of Unibroue’s La Terrible, which I also very much enjoyed.

This beer was sampled at the San Diego Real Ale Festival courtesy of the great Dr. Bill. This beer poors a cornicopia of colors with a light red/orange mix with hints of yellow thrown into a cloudy mix. The head was thick and voluptuous...a big frothy white mound that refused to subside.. a great looking beer. The aroma was a lot of bananas with lemons and grapefruit in there as well. Hints of malt, though well hidden and a touch of alcohol. The flavor yields absolutely NO alcohol presence which is very scary given that this is 10% ABV. Banana and cloves are all over this beer with a wonderful countering sweet finish. A tad bit of roast and heavy fruit spices finish this dry ending. Hints of ginger and nectar in the finish..very complex and very good. A good amount of carbonation...very well rounded beer!

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2004 yum.  Finally had this bottle from Beers of the World.  Pours a wonderful dark mahogany brown, with a good beige head.  Lacing and lots of lively carbonation compliments of the bottle conditioning.  Looks the part so far.  Aroma gives off lots of alcohol, figs, dark prunes, some light chocolate, with an ample amount of yeast.  Flavor is truly great.  Perfect balance of malt, yeast and hops.  Lightly acidic, hardly any astringency, not overly sweet or bitter, just wonderfully complex.  Figs, raisins, earthy barley, cola, pepper.  Lots of dry nuttiness.  Great stuff, maybe a bit too much spice on the finish, but still wonderful.  Medium-full to full bodied, lively carbonation.

Orange gold color. Large white foamy head. Aroma is fruity and sweet. Medium to full-bodied quad. Malts are fruity and sweet. Dark fruits. Touches of spice and herbs. Brown sugar and molasses.  Very smooth tasting. Nice balance. Mouthfeel is very full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

Bottle: Pours with a large tan head, very nice.  Hazy ruby/amber in color.  Smells like yeast, spice, bread, wood, butter, and candy.  Taste is not quite as complex and great as the aroma, but still very good with notes of sweet malt, spice (pepper, cinamon, clove), fruit, and some alcohol at the end.  I think Ill grab another bottle of this and age it.

Pours a lightly hazy red-orange color, and is topped by a tan head.  There is a spicy, yeasty, and bready aroma that is complimented by notes of caramel and toasted biscuits.  Upon first taste, I think that this is a nice full flavored beer.  It is sweet up front with an off dry finish.  It tastes of cinnamon and has a bit of astringency in the finish.  Up front this tastes of caramel, fresh bread, a bit of orange, and honey.  This is so smooth, and oh so drinkable (it is a dangerous combination).  I definitely like this, though it could perhaps use a bit more of the bottle-advertised hops.
This one was pretty cool. Wasnt exactally what I was expecting and stuff but it was still fun to drink. Copper amber with a white medium lasting head. Malty and overall pretty good.
Cloudy copper with tan head.  Aroma of yeast, fruit, candy.  Pleasant.  Mouthfeel was good.  Taste was fruity and spicy.  Good drink.  Thanks, Andy, for sharing.
Medium hazy copper with nice head.  Aroma was woodsy, with a touch of sourness.  Malty  flavors of caramel blended with peaches, dark fruit, and warming alcohol.  Nice.  Love this brewer.

Pours with a two-finger head that fades slowly leaving thick lace.  Slightly cloudy amber color.  Very good carbonation - pour slowly.  Nose has a hint of musty flowers and some raisin.  Sweet, heavy bodied and just hints of the high ABV, should be savored.  $10.25 for a 750ml bottle from Colonial Spirits Acton, Ma.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2009 Dark deep red or copper color.  The head remained the same throughout the pour.  Definite fruit aroma. Very complex smells. Good mouth feel with equally complex flavors.  Fruit, yeast, and I would agree with a buttery aftertaste.  Quite tasty.  If only I was patient enough to age a bottle. 9/5/9/5/19. 

2005 750ml bottle aged at least 3 years and consumed in 2008. Pours a muddy brown with a patchy head of tight white bubbles. Aroma is fruity and yeasty but muddied. Flavors are better; yeast is there and alcohol. But the spices, raisins, and fig flavors round out the flavor profile. Age has not been kind; everything is muted and dull. 6/3/6/3/15

slightly cloudy amber, off white head.  dried fruit, plums, booze, toffee aroma with some dark buttered bread.  the flavour is sweet buttery and boozy, but not as nicely complex as the aroma.  still quite tasty.
UPDATED: NOV 8, 2005 Reallly nice beer, with flavors of port wine, spice and nutmeg.

Dark copper in colour with a cream coloured head.  Aroma was yeasty, malt, sugar and oranges.  Flavour was slightly yeasty, caramel sweetness, some malt, creamy.  Medium-large body with some alcohol coming through.  Finishes with a slight alcohol heat, smooth and pretty well balanced.  Not bad.
Aroma of malt, hops and brown sugar. Amber/red with  a cream coloured head. Flavours are hops, malt,caramel and demerara. Medium bodied, well balanced. Fabulous! Thanks joey_capps!

The beer disembogues from the corked 750ml brown bottle a nebulous mahogany color, the head is spumescent and behemothic in size, the color a winsome tan, as it ever so slowly fades, the lace forms a glutinous sheet to obscure the glass. The nose has a nice aroma of yeast, backed by some fusel alcohol, hints of fruit, over ripe plums comes to mind, with the start sweet and nicely malted, the top is moderate in its feel to the palate. Finish has is stern in its acidity, somewhat tart, the hops delectable in their spicy bite, and the aftertaste maintains the dry tartness to the very end, a nice bit of warming in the tummy also noticed from the 10 percent ABV. My thanks goes to Argo0 for this bottle which he gave me at our little gathering at Papago.

Soft sweetness light woody bitterness, sugars and touch of yeast. Ruby red, cloudy with thick head. Nice feel, sits well. Sweetness is subdue by hefty alcohol, decent balancing. Quality yes, but did not impressed me with anything special.
Pours mahogany, full tan head. Aroma is full with yeast, spice, malt, banana and nutmeg. Flavor is kind of raisiny, sweet, malty, yeasty. Creamy mouthfeel, nice alcohol masking. Very enjoyable.

This bottle is absolutely beautiful and I would expect nothing less from the contents inside said bottle and I am not disappointed.  A slight German hefeweizen yeasty taste with some banana and clove, peeking through with some tart spices, of nutmeg and cinnamon and also some other dark fruits, such as figs and raisins.  The mouthfeel is rich and creamy with some caramel toffee notes, the aftertasteis very nice and lingering.  This could age for years to come and I would be curious to see how it mellows.

Pours a burnt caramel color with a large off-white head.  Aroma is spice, fruit and malt.  Flavor is alcohol, spice, dark fruit and peaches.  Also some candy sugar in this one.  Body is very full and finishes somewhat dry.

Caramel color body with a massive, foamy off-white head. Strong esters in the nose. Includes bubble gum, chocolate, and some port. Flavor is of plums, raisins, and leather. Very winey. Full, viscous mouthfeel. Syrupy even.
Pours orangeish red with a massive thick off white head. Light citrus, banana, yeasty nose. Light banana taste. Mildly wine-like. Has a bitter finish that is slightly metallic.

Body is dark amber and copper colour. Aroma is fruity, spicy, and very floral. Taste is malt sweetness, with some fruit characters. Unfortunately, I can also taste some mild alcohol in this one. leaves a slight fruity aftertaste with some alcohol in the back of the throat. Thanks a lot Joey Capps for getting this one!

Amber w/ ruby hue. Cloudy w/ some sediment. Big fluffy beige head. Yeasty, fruity, & malty nose. Medium, highly carbonated feel. Yeasty fruity flavour of banana & peach w/ an underlying caramel-y maltiness & slight sourness. Dry, peppery finish.
Hazy roby-amber colour. Aroma with robust and yeasty with some alcohol warmth. Flavours of brown sugar and plum, with a decent hop finish.

Surprisingly mediocre offering from what really good brewer.  Copper-tan colour.  Aroma is alcohol, grapes, clove and yeast.  This doesnt come together very well and does not offer anything that stirs the senses.  Dryish palate.  Some maltiness and a little bit of fruitiness.  By the numbers quad.

Nice dark amber body witha  solid head. Alcohol is apparent in the flavour profile, but not as much as it could be given the high octane of this brew. Nice hoppy aroma, of a body that is sweetly malty with hints of sugars. Nice find Joey_Capps.

This belgian pous with a nice reddish-amber body topped by a thick, off-white head with lots of lacing.  The aroma is sweet and malty with notes of candy sugar and a hint of spice.  Theres also a nice fruity accent.  The flavor is sweet malty and slightly yeasty with a nice spicy note.  Full bodied, warming and slightly dry.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2005 Re-rate Flavor more complete on 2nd try. Sharpnes of alcohol minimized. Lively apples in this one.

OK, this bottle wins style points! Speaking of bottles, this quad poured bottle brown, with some red hues, a sight to behold! The aroma had some banana & cloves, with the alcohol peeking. The flavor is appropriately a quad, but the strength of all the flavors (plum, toffee, raisin) was muted. This might be due to how young the beer was upon consumption. Im stashing another for future comparison. Finish was typical Allagash, long and dry.

Rucy red to deep copper in color with a small off-white head.Huge malty,yeasty noce with a touch of alcohol and spice. Flavor is sweet and sour, malty,fruity,yeast and alcohol again. This beer has an amazing mouthfeel,filling and lingering.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2004 Pours with a very nice fluffy head. Aroma is slight hay, fruits, and chocolates. Flavor is a very nice blend of soft chocolate, fruit and a mild belgian yeast quality. Palate is amazingly creamy. Great quad. Alcohol is hard to detect. It is very flavorful yet soft and easy to drink.

Dark redish brown color with a large foamy head. Malty aroma with hints of plum and candi sugar. Dry mouthfeel with alot of fruitiness. Hints of raisins and candy sweetness. Fairly dry and hoppy finish. Prickly carbonation. Alcohol is well concealed. Not too shaby.

Large tan head, excellent retention and lace that klings to the glass relenlessly. hazy, iced tea color. Fruity nose, raisiny, musty and a pleasent yeastiness with a touch of alcohol. Med/full body, creamy texture. Fruity flavors, alcohol, hints of chocolate and an inviting spiceyness. Finish is dry, fruity. The alcohol becomes more evident as it warms but does,nt take anything away from this lovely brew. Nice.

Pours cloudy amber color with an enormous white head that lasts quite a while.  Aroma is very malty with slight toffee and grapefruit notes.  Taste is similarly quite malty and sweet, offset nicely by a touch of acidic bitterness and alcohol.  Very enjoyable.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2004 11/28/04 Rerate-Bubblegumish and very sweet maybe a little too sweet!

Drank on a warm spring evening amoung friends.  Delicious beer.  Amber colored with a froth white head.  Aroma of yeast and light candi sugar.  Well balanced and well crafted.  Malt flavors were apparent along with slight touches of alcohol.  Very good beer
Art of Beer 04:  Clear brown with big wite head. Toffee and alcohol malt aroma with a bit of fruit.   Very smooth and sweet.  Very good, but could be less sweet to be really great.

Burnt amber in color with a nice fluffy white head.  Yeast, candi sugar, slight banana aroma.
Nice balance between malt and hops, cant really single out either.
Medium body, lots going on with the taste.  I detect the alcohol, but by no means overpowering.
One of the best beers I had in months.

Light ruby brown colored. Decent sized head and lace that will not die. Wonderful nose of pear, bubblegum, banana, toffee and more. Medium bodied, suprisingly light texture, may be called watery by some, fruit phenols evident, smooth, herbal, scrumptous yeast and hops come through in finish. Tasty brew, drinks too damn easy for its stength. Needs more texture and time to age IMO. A bit underwhelmed at this one but still very young and improves as warms past cellar.

Deep cloudy copper topped by healthy beige foamy head.  Aroma is mild sweet, herbal, pepper.  Taste is medium sweet, herbal.  The alcohol is well hidden, though the fullness of the smooth body lets you know youre not just drinking lemonade.  Still, remarkably drinkable.
(750ml bottle) Pours a medium, white head and an orange body. Lively carbonation. Nose of red licorice, melon and malt. Slightly fruity flavour. Excellent! Thanks to MaiBockAddict for sharing this...

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2007 Holy popped cork.  Pour is a surprisingly transparent amber.copper color with a frothy off-white head with a twinge of yellow.  Yeast, cloves and peppers in the nose.  Slight pineness to the aroma as well.  Bitter earthy finish.  STart is sweet carbonated moving to some maltiness.  A different brew.  COlor is too clear.  A bit too overcarbonated and the bitterness at the end is a little much(8/3/7/4/15 3.7).------- 7/28/07-------& a shitty initial rating.  Sweet, malty start which has some spiciness and brown sugary flavors in the middle.  Very smooth and creamy.  Some nice estery flavors are also there.  Leathery flavors with some cigar notes are also present to finish.  This is 10%?  Damn, its smooth.  Current rating reflects most recent sample.
This is a great Quad.  Malty, sweet, and pepper flavor.  Finishes smooth, clean, and creamy.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2004 Average score posted.Re-rate. Sweet candy sugar and tart yeast character to the aroma. Deep brown with tan head that recedes to cover. Simple and sweet flavour with notes of chocolate and orangeand a touch of alcohol apparent. Light, gently prickling carbonation. Goes down quickly for a 10% ABV. Bottle enjoyed with MartinT, Rastacouere and beerbuzzmontreal.Original rating (9-5-8-5-17=4.4) Sweet licorice in the nose. Malt, sweet aroma. Clear brown coloured with off-white head that lasts.  Simple, sweet flavour. Great body and wonderful smooth, creamy mouthfeel. This is rather uncomplex and straight forward but clean, sweet and emminently enjoyable. Bottle (at the ratings session post-TapNY). Dont recall who brought this along but thanks - I loved it!

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2006 Peppery hops entangled with sweet, candyish malt...Spicy ashes render liveliness to the good malt cookie body, but this still remains uncomplex for now...The flavors are linear and slightly alcoholic and do not purport any upcoming liveliness...Lets just see how their yeast develops this concoction...3.8/5

Well, an older bottle was corked, and overly yeasty, the candyish maltiness being smothered in fruity uncleanliness...Quite disappointing coming from Allgash...3.1/5
This was a pretty good quad.  It poured a medium amber color with a thin white head.  The taste was balanced and the finish was smooth.  Worth a try.

750 ml bottle, post TAP NY tasting.  Right after the Achel Extra, and a nice comparison was made.  Clear bronze, no head.  Sweet, syrupy peaches in the nose, rather "fresh" tasting for this style I think.  Ultra-creamy palate, interesting herbal notes throughout:  orangepeel hear, white pepper there, ah a bit of ginger and some more pungent rosemary and tarragon near the final drops.  Wonderful, for me just a tiny bit less impressive than the closer-to-style Achel.

Big bottle.  First pour is clear amber with one inch head with staying power.  Musty aroma - earthy and sweet of composted leaves - nearly sublime.  Rich flavor:  pears and walnuts.  Up there with Ommegang's Three Philosphers - just no cherry. But this one is an extra 40% in price.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2005 poured a hazed cranberry-laced and lightly muddy amber color with shreaks of orange and red bleeding through..a head of small bubbles rose tall...an unsubtle aroma of pear, papaya, green raisin, dried pineapple, white pepper, coconut, and cloves flowed through the air like the salmon of Capistrano...malty introduction to a caramelized fruit salad of pears, apples, and sugarplums..firm belgian yeast notes.. waves of sweetness cut short by solid bitterness...gaseous carbination...heated alcohol..dried fruit aftertaste..quite nice.

Lightly cloudy ruby orange color with a dense inch lid of beige bubbles. Fruity aroma. Lots of pears, bananas and pineapple with an underlying of toffee. Creamy feel. Very mellow and light for the stated heft. Flavors do match with the aromas with a touch more light candi. Almost to smooth for its own good.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2008 Burnt reds and oranges, fluffy and thick off white head.  Nose & flavor are similar and with lots going on. Spicy bread dough, toffee, pear, fuzzy fruits, and a hint of banana.  Nice balance, with hops to round it out.  Medium bodied, fizzy end, 10% not really found anywhere. Great stuff!

Pours a beautiful reddish amber color.  Thick mouthfeel, not unexpected for a quad.  Strong alchohol presence, as you would expect in a quad; it is "only" 10% but seems even higher in the mouth feel and taste.  With four kinds of malts and four kinds of hops it is ... that's right, malty, hoppy, and complex.  Taste of dark sweet malt, toffee, sweet spice, and dried fruit.  Really nice, no question about it, but I think I preferred the bready, yeasty Allagash triple.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2007 Bottle... This beer rocks!... Hazy, burnt orange colored ale with a mid-sized, creamy, off-white head. Good retention. Thick, creamy lacing. The aroma is of caramel, toffee, pear, cinnamon and banana. Perfectly-balanced, malty flavor. Some caramel and toffee. Well-bittered, but not overly so. The alcohol is very well-hidden. Medium-bodied (unique for a quad) with a creamy/resiny mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation. Lengthy, lightly bitter, dry finish. World class brew!

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2005 Poured a reddish amber color with an off white head that quickly disappeared.  Sweet and spicy hop aroma.  Also in the aroma was some sweet caramel malt and slight yeast.  Sweet and stickly hop taste.  Adaquately spiced, and a warming presence from the alcohol.  Aged nearly a year, this has improved big time from a fresh sample.

Deep clear red, huge whitish head.  Beautiful nose, sugary and sweet, very fruity with lots of plums, peaches and apricots.  Tastes yummy, big yeasty character, malts are bready.  Subtle fruits, berries and a bit peachy.  Good hop and spice mix at the end.  Great palate, full and coaty, sticks around the mouth.  Good stuff.

With the yeast in, it is a like a piece of copper in strange light that goes from light to black.  This beer has the perfect mouthfeel.  I should be able to give it a "6".
Deep caramel nose, with some bready yeast.  Sweet ending that gets sweeter and sweeter long after you finish drinking it.  A few years in the bottle will do wonders for this.

Bottled on 3-12-04.Aroma of fresh belgian yeast(bubblegum),candy sugar,good malts(caramel,toffee)fresh hops(fruit)and some notable octane.Appearance is lovely and mysterious(hazy garnet/amber,nice tan head with some nice lace).The flavors are great in this young state and like others have stated age may work wonders on this one.Palate is very smooth(could be fuller though) with a nice hop tingle.10% is integrated well(warms the esophogus).Aftertaste has a nice slightly stringbeany taste.I like this beer and will lay one down for a year to see what happens.This one goes down faster than expected.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2004 750ml Corked ,Batch #1 I believe. Pours a beautiful amber which is cloudy and with a fiery orange hue and a thick dense and frothy head. Head settles down a bit but retains well. Fantastic aroma, sugary, malty with notes of cherries, yeast and spices like pepper and clove. Wonderful. The mouthfeel is creamy, full and smooth with a delicate feel and a lively carbonation. The flavor is also one to desire. A sugary, malty spicy treat that has a faint and enjoyable hop presence which lends a slight grassy note. No signs of the 10% abv anywhere in aroma or flavor. Not as complex or deep a flavor as some Belgian Quads we all are familiar with but I wasn't expecting that either. This is an American brew. Maybe with time it will mature a bit but it's wonderful right now in my opinion. An incredibly enjoyable flavor. This one's a winner folks. The best Allagash has brewed in my humble opinion. Way to go guys!
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Pours a mix of garnet and amber. Generous tan head. Nose is spice, very light sugary notes, dark fruit and malt. The taste is wonderful! Spice and yeast along with some candy sugar and malts. There is a peppery hint to it along with a fruit taste. Very carbonated mouthfeel. Has that standard Belgian style carbonation sharpness. The finish is rather mild, the carbonation notwithstanding. There's some more spice in the finish and more fruit. This is damn good, but I'm sure 6 months to a year will do wonders for this. I'll let you know next April!

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2004 Brown/orange color with a yeast aroma. Very nice spicy taste, with some fruit as well. Finishes a little bitter, with a hop taste. Really well done, easy to drink, and should age well. If I can get enough, and hold off drinking it, I'll age some.

Pick up a bottle of this if you can. Wonderful yeasty, malty aroma over a light brown pour. Heavy alcohol is masked by some fruity notes (strawberries?)Wll hopped for a begian. Hard to put down, but at 10%, you shouldn't drink much of this one. A classic, unique in every way.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2004 Heavy fruity aromas. Bubble gum. Touch of spice. Nicely hopped creating a good balance with the fruit and malt. Touch of sweetness. Carbonation gives the beer fairly lively and refreshing texture for such a high ABV beer. Ill agree with jeffc666 and label this dangerously drinkable as well  almost like sody pop. Could use some grown-up complexity, but I am enjoying it and need to slow down and drink this 750 a little more slowly. I too will go back try to pick up a bottle for aging.
Nice brownish color. It could use some aging. Aroma of hops and bubble gum. Really good beer. Very hoppy flavor. It finishes sweet. Will get getting some more to age.

(Consumed at 60F) Beautiful sparkling red-orange body. The tan rocky head creates excellent glass lacing. The aroma is sweet with tons of yeast and dark fruit. Flavor-wise this beer is beautiful, sweet candi sugar, some spicy hops come into the picture about mid way through. The body is medium-full with slight bitterness and a little bit of a alcohol numbing. Overall an outstanding efort from Allagash. Not as complex as the Belgian Abts but dangerously drinkable. That 10% ABV is pretty uch totally hidden.

This is worthy of some extended aging. Nice Brownish orange color. Aroma is a menage of hops, bubble gum (which I would attribute to being young), and candi. Flavor is bold. Sticky sweetness blended with lots of hop flavor, and a tad bit of bitterness. Finishes long and sweet. Will be buying a couple more.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: An American craftbrewing tour de force. Aroma is plum preserves with a powerful whack of Belgian yeast, slight vinegar, and a powdery CO2 quality when sniffed in the snifter. Somewhat pheremonic. Tremendous appearance -- tall, heavy Belgian bottle with gold lettering.  Dark oak colored brew with off-white microbubble head that coats the sides of the glass nicely. Superbly balanced. Initially lightly sweet, with dark candy flavors.  It has an almost herbal bittering. Finish is lightly nut-bitter, which persists for quite a while. Sometimes it was almost too smooth.  If I had a minor complaint, it was that it sometimes grew watery or vacant in its smoothness.  Be sure to drink it warm for the full body and complexity.  If the Allagash guys see this and have a few cases which are about to expire, I'll take them off your hands.

Interesting - I am the 4th rater of "4". Pours a dark walnut brown color with a tight off-white head - decent lacing. Multi-faceted aroma - fresh fruit basket, chewing tobacco, and pepper. Alcohol (10%)is hidden extremely well. Flavor, not as rich as I had hoped. Good, hearty maltiness, just a bit thin for a Quad. Has some Cascade hoppiness to it with grapefruit esences and a bit of cotton candy sugar sweetness. The aftertaste is a bit metallic however. Still a good American Quad though. Probably would do well with some aging - I just do not have the patience!

750ml at 9.79 a bottle but well worth it.  enjoyed it in a chimay trappist glass.  awesome aroma of malt, fruit, and alcohol.  beautiful brown-orange color with a lasting creamy head and lasting carbonation.  super mouthfeel, best i've had in a while.  you can taste all the sugars and malt. yummy.  The box that i took this bottle out of said bottled on march 12 2004.  In my opinion, you can taste the lack of aging.  The hop bite is very evident and is the only disapointment.  this beer is good now, 2-3 years it'll be a contender with any quads and worth it's hefty price.  oh, you will feel the alcohol in this one, no doubt about it, cheers.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2004 Woohoo, its pretty cool to be one of the first raters on a beer that is going to get a lot of exposure! I feel like Im a Hollywood beer agent; See, see, see, I discovered this! Ahhhh I didnt do shit, I just went to the store and bought an expensive bottle of beer; Im the same old looser Ive always been!    
 Pours with a foggy mahogany body and a small but dense off white head. The aroma is malty and yeast. Radiating notes of toffee, dates, raisins, and warm wheat bread covered with chopped almonds and honey butter are drawing me in. 
The flavor, the flavor, Ohhhh the f-l-a-v-o-r!! Lets talk about a cornucopia filled with all the most wonderful dark fruits in North America.. and more! Plums, apricots to no end, gooey ripened dates rolled in brown sugar, mid-summer cherries those cherries that are plump and overly ripe about to burst theyre so ripe and sweet. A fresh loaf of  dark bread, pumpernickel or a toasty dark wheat but with tangerine zest baked in to add so citric quality; a peppery spiciness, a sprinkling of cardamom, and nutmeg. The creamy palate will lift your spirit and soften your soul. Soooo very Nice!  
 I will be buying a few more bottle of this before its gone. I could do a side-by-side with any Trappist Quad and never know that this wasnt a peer. A year in my cellar would add the most amazing complexity to a brew that is already an artesian compilation! 
 Recommended

Bottled:  Pours a brilliant ruddy orange brown.  Perfect cream colored foam head.  Substantial lacing.  Nose is perfumey, fruit, pineapple, evident alcohol and yeast.  Oh geeez, this is a real treat.  Perfect mouthfeel.  Medium bodied, velvety smooth.  Steady carbonation.  Chcolate sundae, cherry on top.  Dark fruit, bittersweet chocolate, pineapple, white pepper, raison, black cherry.  A belly, feet, finger, brain warmer.  Yo, this is from Maine, unbelievable...A palate blaster, and I am seriously impressed.  Ill leave it at that...GET SOME!  Rob Tod, you are the friggin MAN!
